The U.S. Congress is in a crisis, unable to decide on its next House Speaker, an elected position that is second in line to the president. For months, the position has been vacant, with political parties unable to come to a consensus on who should be chosen. It is a crisis that has paralyzed the institution, leading to a host of legislative deadlocks and a lack of progress in Washington.

At the root of the crisis is the fact that the House of Representatives is currently split between Democrats and Republicans, with no one party in control. As a result, both sides have put forth competing candidates for the role of Speaker of the House. Democrats have nominated Nancy Pelosi, the current House Minority Leader, while Republicans are backing Kevin McCarthy, the House Majority Leader.

The power struggle has led to a total stalemate in Washington, as neither candidate has been able to garner enough votes from both sides to win the office. The problem is compounded by the fact that many members of Congress are unwilling to break party lines to vote for the other side’s candidate.

The consequences of the Speaker’s crisis have been far-reaching. Without a Speaker in place, important legislation on a host of issues, including healthcare, immigration, and gun control, has failed to pass through Congress. The lack of progress has led to significant frustration among the American public, who feel that the power struggles in Washington have made it impossible for government to actually get anything done.

The inability to choose a Speaker has also led to gridlock within Congress. For example, the House and Senate have been unable to come to an agreement on a budget for the coming year. Without a budget, Congress is unable to pass any appropriations bills, making it difficult for the government to pay for its operations.

Moreover, the Speaker debacle has thrown a wrench into the confirmation process for federal judges, cabinet secretaries, and other government officials. With no one in charge of the House, the confirmation process has become stalled, delaying the confirmation of much-needed personnel.

In an effort to resolve the crisis, House Democrats have proposed a number of reforms, including opening up the Speaker’s race to a wider pool of candidates. They have also proposed rules changes that would give members of Congress more leeway to break party lines and vote for the candidate of their choice.

While it remains to be seen if these reforms will be able to break the logjam, they do represent a small glimmer of hope in an otherwise paralyzing situation. Ultimately, it will take a combination of compromise and political courage to break the impasse and fill the Speaker’s office. Until then, the American people will be left wondering how long their government will remain in gridlock.

Africa has been making great strides in its energy transition to more sustainable sources, but the progress is still painfully slow. Despite billions of dollars of investment, the continent remains a huge outlier when it comes to accessing electricity.

It is estimated that 600 million people in Africa have no access to power, meaning they rely on candles, wood, kerosene and gas for their energy needs. This has a profound effect on their lives: lack of access to energy means a lack of opportunities for development and improved living conditions.

But the challenge of bringing power to the continent is an arduous one. The continent is vast and sparsely populated in many places, which means the cost of creating and maintaining a grid infrastructure for electricity is high. It also means that the people who need it the most are often the hardest to reach.

The region is also blessed with an abundance of renewable energy sources: the sun shines year-round, the wind blows constantly and rivers provide potential for hydroelectric power. But the challenge lies in finding ways to capture and store that energy in an efficient and cost effective way.

Currently, more than two-thirds of Africa’s energy comes from burning coal and oil. This has huge environmental and economic consequences and is also a huge drag on the continent’s economic growth. The International Energy Agency estimates that sub-Saharan Africa loses $25 billion a year due to energy poverty.

Fortunately, there are steps being taken to try to tackle the problem. The African Development Bank is investing $12 billion to try and improve access to electricity in 30 African countries by 2025. The United Nations has an initiative to give access to energy in 200 African countries by 2030.

One of the main focuses of these programs is to support the development of renewable energy sources such as solar and wind. These sources are seen as being more reliable, resilient and cost-effective than coal and oil.

In addition to this, Africa is also looking into decentralizing its energy production and introducing distributed networks of small-scale power producers. This will make it easier for people in rural areas to access the power they need.

Africa has the potential to become a major global leader in renewable energy and clean technologies, but it needs to overcome its significant infrastructure challenges to do so. It is encouraging to see that steps are being taken to try and tackle the energy poverty that so many African people face, but it is clear that there is still much work to be done.

text: To understand money , let 's first pose a hypothetical of what society would be like without it . We 'll use a simple agrarian ( farming ) society . On your farm you grow wheat and raise pigs . You 're very good at this , and produce 100 bushels of wheat a year and 5 fat pigs , and you need 20 bushels and 1 pig to feed your family . This leaves you with 80 bushels and 4 pigs to trade . Why would you trade ? Well , you need a plough to help you grow wheat , and the plough needs a horse to pull it . You do n't know how to make a plough , and your horse is getting old . Luckily for you , the blacksmith has both , but you already gave him food when he made you a scythe . He does however want some charcoal to run his forge , and the charcoal maker needs food , so you go over to him and give him some , take his charcoal to the blacksmith and give it to him . This is what is known as a * barter based * economy . It 's all about the exchange of goods . The problem with this system , is that it does n't always work . What if the charcoal maker did n't need wheat , but the fisherman did ? How many people would you have to go through to get your plough ? Due to this , many societies developed some form of currency ( money ) , which has no value in and of itself , but represents the ability to buy something . Instead of trading until you get what you need , you take your food to market , and sell it for 10 clam shells . You can then give the blacksmith 8 of these in exchange for the horse and plough . He can spend them on whatever he wants to , and you get what you need . The clamshell represents a future or past trade . The problem with this system is that if someone finds 10 000 clam shells , all of a sudden the current shells in circulation are worth less . People can lose faith in the system , as the 10 clamshells they got yesterday are now worth much less than they were then . This is called * hyperinflation * , and it often leads to people reverting to barter based systems . To reduce the risk of this , government 's take control of the production of money , and attempt to limit the amount in circulation . The advantage of a money system over a barter system is that it allows for greater specialisation and services . A doctor has a very valuable service some of the time for some people , but is worthless to most people . In a barter system they 'd have to wait for the farmer to get sick before they could get food ( and even then they might be shortchanged ) , in a money based system , they can treat the blacksmith , and use the money from that to pay the farmer or fisherman .

It's been nearly two years since the United States saw a major election shakeup. With Democrats now firmly in control of the White House, it's easy to forget that Republicans had a slight majority in the House of Representatives prior to the 2020 election. But with the 2022 midterm elections just around the corner, political analysts are warning that a Republican resurgence could have drastic implications for the technology sector.

For the past four years, tech companies have largely seen a "hands-off" approach from the Democratic majority, with only a few high-profile exceptions like the repeal of Section 230, the repeal of the Obama-era net neutrality rules, and antitrust investigations into Google, Apple, and other large tech firms. But if Republicans are able to regain control of Congress, that could all change.

"There are some people who believe that if the Republicans gain control, there's going to be a much more hostile environment for tech companies," said Robert Atkinson, the founder of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation think tank. "That could manifest itself in the form of more regulation or restrictions on what they can do. It could also open up the door to a much more protectionist approach, which could be disruptive."

One of the potential issues on the Republican agenda is repealing or significantly revising the 1996 Communications Decency Act, which has been used to protect social media and internet companies from liability for user-generated content. Some Republicans have argued that these protections have allowed companies to shirk responsibility for their content moderation decisions, an argument that could gain traction if the GOP takes control of Congress.

There are also concerns that a Republican majority would push for stricter data privacy legislation, which could have far-reaching implications for the tech sector. Atkinson believes this is a real possibility, noting that many GOP legislators have pushed for legislation that would impose tougher restrictions on the way companies use and store consumer data.

"If Republicans come to power, I think that's definitely one of the things that's going to be on their agenda," Atkinson said.

While it's unclear how exactly the tech industry would be affected by a Republican-controlled Congress, one thing is certain: the landscape of the sector is set to change drastically if that happens. Companies may find themselves facing increased regulation or restrictions, while others could see an opportunity to gain an edge over their competition by exploiting the new landscape.

Atkinson noted that while the short-term effects of such a major shakeup may be unknown, the long-term implications could be profound.

"It could be an incredibly disruptive period of time for the technology sector, depending on how Republicans decide to approach things," he said.

Whether or not Republicans manage to regain control of Congress in 2022, the tech industry is sure to be watching the election results closely. With the possibility of major disruption looming on the horizon, the sector could be in for a wild ride.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Hardline Republican lawmakers on Thursday vowed to block Rep. Kevin McCarthy's bid for the role of Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, citing a sharp divide among the party's ranks over his leadership style.

The House will vote for a new Speaker on Jan. 3 and McCarthy, the current House majority leader, is seen as the heavy favorite for the job. But a handful of vocal conservative members of the House, calling themselves the Freedom Caucus, said they oppose McCarthy due to his tendency to reach across the aisle and to compromise on conservative principles.

"We've seen too much bipartisanship and not enough adherence to conservative values," Rep. Mark Meadows (R-NC) told reporters at a press conference Thursday. "We cannot support a Speaker who is willing to water down our principles and pass legislation that goes against our core values."

Meadows, who heads the Freedom Caucus, said the group will meet on Friday to decide on a candidate they can support for Speaker. Until then, they said, they will withhold their support for McCarthy.

The group was a major factor in the 2015 ouster of Speaker John Boehner, who faced a wave of criticism from conservatives for negotiating with Democrats on key issues. McCarthy was expected to take up the mantle from Boehner, but it appears those expectations will have to be put on hold for the time being.

"Our caucus is unified in our opposition to Kevin McCarthy," said Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH). "We have a very clear sense of what it takes to lead the House and he doesn't meet that standard. We're not going to stand for it."

The opposition to McCarthy has cast doubt on the outcome of Thursday's election. If the Freedom Caucus' members vote against him, he could potentially lose the race, despite having a solid majority within the GOP. In that case, the election could stretch on for days, as members search for a consensus Speaker.

"We're not trying to upset the apple cart," Meadows said. "We simply want to make sure the person leading this House is someone who will fight for our principles."

The situation has put the party's leadership in a tough spot. While GOP leaders are eager to get someone in the Speaker's chair as soon as possible, they also don't want to risk alienating conservative members of the caucus, who could push for further intra-party battles in the coming months.

For now, it appears the party will have to remain in a holding pattern until the Freedom Caucus decides on a suitable candidate or McCarthy manages to convince its members of his loyalty to conservative principles. It could be the start of an unpredictable and lengthy process for a job that just weeks ago seemed guaranteed to go to McCarthy.

A supercharger, on the other hand, is a type of air compressor that is driven directly by the engine. This means that it can provide boost as soon as the engine is started, but it also means that it consumes more power from the engine to run. So, which one is better? AMD has acknowledged that the cause of the issue was “not with the product itself”, but with “the setup provided by certain partners”.

To fix the issue, AMD has said that users should ensure that their water cooling system is running optimally, with adequate water flow and coolant temperature.

The company has also offered to provide a replacement water cooling system to any customer who has purchased an affected Radeon RX 7900 XTX card.

AMD has not yet revealed the identity of any affected partners, but the company has said that the issue only affects a “small” number of users, so those with Radeon RX 7900 XTX cards should be mostly unaffected.

While it’s unfortunate that this issue had to be addressed so soon after launch, it’s reassuring to see that AMD is taking action to ensure that any affected users are not left with a suboptimal experience.

The company has also said that it will continue to investigate the issue and work with partners to identify and address any similar thermal issues.

text: A search algorithm is a method for finding a specific item or group of items in a larger data set. Search algorithms are a fundamental part of computer science and are used to efficiently locate specific items within data structures such as arrays, lists, and trees. Some common search algorithms include linear search, binary search, and depth-first search.    Linear search is a simple search algorithm that involves looking through each item in a list, one by one, until the desired item is found. This method is relatively slow, especially for large lists, but it is easy to understand and implement.    Binary search is a more efficient search algorithm that is used on sorted lists. It works by dividing the list in half and checking to see if the desired item is in the first or second half. If it is not, the algorithm repeats the process on the appropriate half until the item is found or it is determined that the item is not in the list.    Depth-first search is a search algorithm used for traversing tree data structures. It involves exploring as far as possible down one branch before backtracking and exploring other branches. Depth-first search can be used to find specific items in a tree or to traverse the entire tree for some other purpose.    There are many other types of search algorithms, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. The choice of which search algorithm to use depends on the specific requirements of the task at hand.

As you fall, you will keep accelerating until you reach a certain speed, called terminal velocity. This is the fastest speed you can reach while falling. At terminal velocity, the force of gravity is balanced by the air resistance, or drag, that you experience as you fall. This is why you stop accelerating at some point - the air resistance is strong enough to balance out the force of gravity, so you stop moving faster and faster. Imagine you are holding a ball and you drop it. At first, the ball will fall slowly because it is not moving very fast. But as it falls, it will pick up speed and start moving faster and faster. The Blue Brain Project is a Swiss brain research initiative that aims to create a digital reconstruction of the mouse brain. The project was founded in May 2005 by the Brain and Mind Institute of École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) in Switzerland. Its mission is to use biologically-detailed digital reconstructions and simulations of the mammalian brain to identify the fundamental principles of brain structure and function.
The project is headed by the founding director Henry Markram—who also launched the European Human Brain Project—and is co-directed by Felix Schürmann, Adriana Salvatore and Sean Hill. Using a Blue Gene supercomputer running Michael Hines's NEURON, the simulation involves a biologically realistic model of neurons and an empirically reconstructed model connectome.
There are a number of collaborations, including the Cajal Blue Brain, which is coordinated by the Supercomputing and Visualization Center of Madrid (CeSViMa), and others run by universities and independent laboratories.

(Reuters) - Wall Street is paying the price for its poor performance this year. On Monday, stocks tumbled as investors dumped riskier assets in response to the fear of further economic woes due to rising Covid-19 cases and fresh restrictions in the U.S. and abroad.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by 1.4 percent, the S&P 500 by 1.2 percent, and the Nasdaq Composite by 1.0 percent. Big losses were seen in the tech and retail sectors, with the Dow Jones tech index falling by 2.1 percent.

The worsening pandemic situation has cast a pall over the U.S. economy and sent riskier assets lower. The number of new daily cases of Covid-19 in the U.S. reached a record high of more than 208,000 on Sunday, and the country is experiencing a new surge in cases in some states.

Meanwhile, more restrictions are being imposed to contain the virus. Several states, including California, are reinstating tougher measures to limit gatherings and force businesses to close.

Moreover, the U.S. economy is still struggling to recover from the pandemic-induced recession. According to the latest data, the unemployment rate remains elevated at 6.7 percent in November, up from 6.5 percent in October, and well above its pre-pandemic level.

The disappointing economic data added to the uncertainty in the markets as investors weighed the prospects for stimulus. Earlier this month, Congressional negotiators struck a deal on a $900 billion stimulus package. But the agreement is yet to be passed by Congress, and it remains unclear when that might happen.

Meanwhile, investors are increasingly becoming worried about the increasing debt burden of the U.S. government. The country's debt is expected to reach its highest level ever, at $29 trillion, this year.

The jittery market sentiment has dented investor sentiment and sent stocks tumbling. Investors are now wondering if Wall Street is on Santa's naughty list this year, as the rally that took the major averages to record highs in November has run out of steam.

On the bright side, the coming weeks are likely to see a pickup in activity as the holiday season kicks off. Many retail stores have already opened their doors for the season, and this could spark some buying interest in stocks.

Moreover, there are still some positive prospects for the markets. The Federal Reserve has already said it would keep rates low for an extended period of time, and the central bank's accommodative stance should provide support for stocks.

In addition, many analysts still think that the vaccine rollout could be the catalyst for a strong recovery in the U.S. economy in 2021. Several countries have already started their vaccine distribution programs, and this could potentially pave the way for an economic rebound.

For now, the markets remain choppy and investors are cautious. With a lack of clarity on the economic and stimulus prospects, Wall Street may remain on Santa's naughty list this year.

text:
A deep learning processor (DLP), or a deep learning accelerator, is an electronic circuit designed for deep learning algorithms, usually with separate data memory and dedicated instruction set architecture. Deep learning processors range from mobile devices, such as neural processing units (NPUs) in Huawei cellphones,
to cloud computing servers such as tensor processing units (TPU) in the Google Cloud Platform.
The goal of DLPs is to provide higher efficiency and performance for deep learning algorithms than general central processing unit (CPUs) and graphics processing units (GPUs) would. Most DLPs employ a large number of computing components to leverage high data-level parallelism, a relatively larger on-chip buffer/memory to leverage the data reuse patterns, and limited data-width operators for error-resilience of deep learning. Deep learning processors differ from AI accelerators in that they are specialized for running learning algorithms, while AI accelerators are typically more specialized for inference. However, the two terms (DLP vs AI accelerator) are not used rigorously and there is often overlap between the two.

The new ban is part of a larger package of measures aimed at stabilizing the Canadian housing market, which has been spiraling out of control in recent years.

The move was made in an effort to protect the Canadian housing market from speculative buyers from abroad and to ensure that Canadian citizens have access to affordable housing in their home country.

The ban comes after other measures have been taken to try to alleviate the housing crisis. For example, Canada recently implemented a 15 percent tax on foreign buyers of residential property in British Columbia, which has been one of the regions hardest hit by skyrocketing prices.

It should also help ensure that Canadian citizens have a more reasonable chance at purchasing a home. After all, if more non-Canadians can purchase homes, this will drive up prices, leaving it harder for Canadians to afford them.

The Canadian government is also hoping that the ban will help control inflation and ease the debt burden for Canadian households. By preventing foreign buyers from buying homes, the government is trying to reduce demand in the market and, in turn, bring prices down.

However, the ban may not have the desired effect. There is a possibility that it could have a negative impact on the Canadian economy, as it could hurt foreign investment in the country.

Reports of young children accidentally eating marijuana edibles have soared in recent years as more states move to legalize the drug, health and medical experts said.

A growing number of states have legalized the drug for recreational and medicinal use, giving rise to a booming industry that has brought the edible form of the drug into a greater range of households.

A study published Monday in the Journal of Pediatrics tracked cases of accidental marijuana ingestion among children younger than 12 in states with marijuana laws allowing recreational use. It found that the number of cases has more than tripled since 2014, with California, Colorado and Washington leading the way.

The study’s authors are calling for tighter regulation to protect children, saying edible marijuana products are often attractive to young children and can be easily mistaken for candy.

"We think these numbers reflect the increased availability of recreational marijuana products in these states,” said Dr. Robert Glatter, an emergency physician at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City who was not involved in the study.

The findings come as states look to further regulate and even ban certain forms of the drug, including edibles.

In California, officials this month proposed tighter restrictions on edible marijuana products, including a ban on candy shapes and packaging that may appeal to children.

Glatter said the study underscores the need for increased awareness of the potential dangers of marijuana edibles and for stronger laws to protect children.

He warned that edibles could potentially be more dangerous than smoking or vaping marijuana because it takes longer for people to experience the effects of the drug when it’s ingested.

“Ingestion of an edible form of marijuana can be more dangerous due to a delay in onset of symptoms,” Glatter said. “Vomiting, agitation, confusion and seizure can occur, and severe cases can include more rapid and deeper levels of unconsciousness.”

The study found that the majority of children who ingest marijuana edibles do not need medical attention. But in some cases, the ingestion can cause serious symptoms, including excessive drowsiness and breathing problems.

The study’s authors suggested more robust child safety packaging and labels that make it clear the products contain marijuana. They also called for more education about the dangers of accidentally ingesting marijuana edibles.

Glatter urged parents to be aware of the potential dangers of marijuana edibles and to take steps to ensure the drugs are not accessible to children. He said it’s important to properly secure the drugs and to keep them out of reach of children.

“Young children often cannot distinguish between edible marijuana products and candy or sweets,” Glatter said. “It’s essential that parents store edibles safely, out of reach and locked up in a medicine cabinet, for example.”

text:
When it comes to getting from Point A to Point B, it's not always easy to find the perfect transportation solution. The e-bike boom is changing the way people get around, providing a quick, easy and inexpensive way to get around cities and beyond. But this newfound freedom of mobility comes with a big challenge—our country's outdated infrastructure.

As electric bikes become more popular, cities, states and the federal government must grapple with how to safely and effectively integrate these vehicles into our existing roadways and sidewalks. With the right policies and investments, the e-bike revolution could unlock greater freedom of mobility and reduce traffic congestion—but it requires an urgent commitment to upgrade our nation’s infrastructure and create a safer, more sustainable transportation network for the future.

The electric bike—or “e-bike”—is a relatively new vehicle category that offers the advantages of a bicycle, but with the added bonus of an electric motor for assistance. It’s quickly becoming an increasingly popular choice for commuters looking for a way to get around faster and with less physical effort. But as demand for these vehicles grows, our outdated roads and sidewalks may not be able to handle the increased traffic.

The existing infrastructure is ill-equipped to accommodate the increase in bikes, and too many roads lack bike lanes or shared use pathways. Without this infrastructure, people on e-bikes are forced to ride on roads with high speed limits and heavy car traffic, which can be dangerous. Even in areas that do have bike lanes and other dedicated space for cyclists, the infrastructure is often inadequate, poorly maintained or lacks sufficient connection to other bike facilities.

Fortunately, the solution is within reach. Our nation needs to prioritize investment in bicycle infrastructure to make it easier, safer and more convenient for people to ride e-bikes. This includes creating more dedicated bike lanes and shared use pathways, expanding existing bike networks, improving connectivity between bike paths, and investing in bike parking and other amenities.

At the same time, we need to create uniform safety rules for e-bikes, including mandatory helmet laws and minimum speed limits. And we need to educate drivers and other cyclists on how to share the road and sidewalks safely with e-bike riders.

The e-bike boom offers an unprecedented opportunity to reduce traffic congestion, improve air quality and increase access to transportation in areas where public transit is limited or unavailable. But in order to unlock these benefits, our nation needs to embrace this new form of mobility and invest in the infrastructure necessary to make it a safe and convenient form of transportation. It's time to navigate the e-bike boom with the right infrastructure in place.

Although Pope Benedict had long been in failing health, the passing of the former pontiff came as a shock to the faithful throughout the world. In response, hundreds of thousands of people flocked to Rome to pay their respects.

The funeral, which was celebrated by Pope Francis, began at 10:00AM at St. Peter's Square. An honor guard of cardinals and bishops walked in a solemn procession bearing the late Pope's body, followed by a large crowd of faithful mourners.

Later that evening, Pope Francis joined thousands of people for a candlelight vigil to remember Pope Benedict. As the crowd lit hundreds of candles and sang together, the Pope spoke of his deep sadness at the passing of Pope Benedict. He said that it was a sorrowful day but that he was determined to carry on the legacy of Pope Benedict and continue the good works that he had started.

After the candlelight vigil, the Pope returned to the Vatican, where he welcomed mourners who wished to pay their respects to the late Pope. The crowd inside the Vatican was silent and reverent, many tears flowing as people held hands and prayed for the soul of their beloved former pontiff.

The funeral of Pope Benedict was a solemn and moving affair, drawing thousands of people from all over the world in a show of faith and love for the former pontiff. text: There are certain standards that modern checks need to meet. These aren't required by law, but banks today generally insist on them. Office supply stores sell check blanks that fit into standard computer printers. This check paper includes the necessary security features of checks, and using the check printing software, you can print your personal information, including your name & address, your bank's name and address, and your account numbers. The account numbers on the bottom of the checks are called the MICR code, which stands for Magnetic Ink Character Recognition. Normally, these numbers were printed with special magnetic ink, which was used in automated check reading machines. Checks that you purchase from your bank still use magnetic ink; however, modern check readers are optical, and don't require magnetic ink. So you should be able to print checks with your printer using standard ink/toner, and not have a problem. Without purpose-specific check printing software, you could still buy blank check paper from the store, and with a little trial-and-error you could print using Excel.  The biggest challenge with doing this would be printing the MICR code: you would probably need to install an MICR font on your computer and play around with the size and location until you get it where you want it.  Doing a little Googling, I see that there are some check printing Excel templates out there, but I haven't tried any of these, and it is unclear to me whether they actually print the MICR, or whether they assume that you have blank checks with the MICR account number and check numbers already printed. Without purchasing blank check paper, you won't have any of the security features, such as microprinting, watermarks, erasure protection, anti-photocopying background, etc.  As you mentioned, if you are depositing checks via mobile phone app, as some banks now allow, none of these security features are doing any good.  The problem, however, is that you are not writing checks for yourself; you are writing checks to other people, and you have no way of knowing whether or not their banks are going to give them trouble with your checks. I recommend sticking with check paper that has the security features because, if nothing else, it will make your check look more like a real check.

The highly-anticipated sequels to Avatar, James Cameron's science fiction blockbuster, have been hit with criticism from some Indigenous groups.

The sequels, which will be released in 2025 and 2027, have come under fire from Indigenous people in the US, Canada, and New Zealand. They claim that the movie perpetuates a “white savior” narrative, in which white people come to the aid of Indigenous people in dire need.

The first Avatar movie was set on a planet populated by the indigenous Na’vi people. The story follows a human military group that attempts to take control of the planet for its resources. The main character, Jake Sully, helps the Na’vi fight back, and ultimately allies with them.

Avatar was widely praised for its visuals and storyline, and was the highest-grossing film of all time until Avengers: Endgame surpassed it in 2019. It was also the first movie to earn more than $2 billion worldwide.

However, some Indigenous activists have pointed out that the movie uses Indigenous people as props to further the white characters’ journeys. They argue that while Avatar may have helped make some people more aware of Indigenous issues, it isn’t a true representation of the cultures and struggles of Indigenous people.

Indigenous activist Crystal Echo Hawk of the IllumiNative organization told the Los Angeles Times, “It’s great to have representation, but it’s not enough to just have a token Indigenous character or presence. We need meaningful, nuanced and accurate stories about us to make change.”

Other Indigenous activists have also voiced their concerns about the sequel. In an open letter, the New Zealand Maori Council said, “We feel these images and portrayals of Maori, and of Indigenous people generally, are unhelpful at best and offensive and destructive at worst.”

The letter calls on Cameron to “seek ways to collaborate with local Maori communities in the production of the sequel” and to “acknowledge and understand the deep-seated cultural and religious issues around representations of Maori people.”

The letter also requests that the film avoid “degrading imagery” such as war dances, hakas, and other Indigenous cultural elements.

In a statement to CNN, Cameron responded to the criticisms, saying “We acknowledge and respect the concerns of the Indigenous community, and we are taking steps to ensure our production is an opportunity for dialogue, education, and positive representation.”

The director said he was working with a team of advisors from the Indigenous community to ensure that the sequels are “authentic and respectful to the Indigenous cultures” featured in the movies.

Cameron added that he hopes the sequels will “help raise awareness about the struggle of Indigenous people in the US, Canada, and New Zealand, and will help promote understanding, reconciliation, and healing.”

The first Avatar sequel is expected to be released in December 2025. Until then, we'll have to wait to see if Cameron and the Indigenous advisors he is working with can make a movie that truly honors the culture and history of the Indigenous people it seeks to represent.

text: In computer science, a parallel random-access machine (parallel RAM or PRAM) is a shared-memory abstract machine. As its name indicates, the PRAM is intended as the parallel-computing analogy to the random-access machine (RAM) (not to be confused with random-access memory). In the same way that the RAM is used by sequential-algorithm designers to model algorithmic performance (such as time complexity), the PRAM is used by parallel-algorithm designers to model parallel algorithmic performance (such as time complexity, where the number of processors assumed is typically also stated). Similar to the way in which the RAM model neglects practical issues, such as access time to cache memory versus main memory, the PRAM model neglects such issues as synchronization and communication, but provides any (problem-size-dependent) number of processors. Algorithm cost, for instance, is estimated using two parameters O(time) and O(time × processor_number).

A tax year is January 1 through December 31 for most taxpayers. To meet the physical presence test, you must be physically present in a foreign country or countries for at least 330 full days during any period of 12 consecutive months.If you qualify for the foreign earned income exclusion, you can exclude up to $107,600 (for tax year 2021) of your foreign earned income from your taxable income. You can also exclude or deduct certain housing costs if you qualify for the exclusion or deduction.It's important to note that you must file a tax return to claim the foreign earned income exclusion, even if you do not owe any taxes. Researchers have been studying Europe’s ancient stone walls for centuries, and for the first time in history, they believe they have solved the mystery of why mysterious circles and lines were engraved into the walls and ceilings of some of the oldest caves in the continent.

The curious patterns, known as ‘ornamentation’, have been spotted in caves all over Europe and were first noted by French anthropologist Henri Breuil in the late 1800s. Though the shapes were almost always found in the same spot, the purpose of their existence remained unknown until recently.

In a new study published in the journal Quaternary International, a team of researchers from the University of Barcelona say they believe the markings were used by our ancestors as a form of communication.

According to the team, the patterns were used by hunters and gatherers to communicate with each other, with the dots representing the locations of different species of game, while the lines indicated pathways. The markings were used to teach each other where to look for game, as well as to help children learn the environment.

The researchers also believe the markings were used to help hunters return to specific locations. It's possible that they used the dot and line patterns to signal to each other when they were able to find a new source of food.

The findings are especially interesting as the ornaments were made by the Upper Paleolithic cave dwellers, who were believed to have only had limited language skills. This study is helping to shed light on how our ancestors were able to communicate with each other and the wider world.

The team studied a total of four sites in two countries, France and Spain, dating from between 36,000 and 10,000 years ago. They found that the dots and stripes were often located in places where there was plenty of game or other food sources.

At one site, there was a large number of dots and lines found in a small area. This has led the researchers to believe that the ancient cave dwellers were using the patterns to signal to one another that they had identified a good hunting ground.

The discovery is exciting for researchers, as it is believed to be the first time that these patterns have been linked to communication between our ancestors. It is also an important step in understanding how these ancient societies organized and operated.

The research also shows that the ancient cave dwellers used sophisticated techniques to communicate with each other, which could be a sign that they had a more developed language than is often thought.

Overall, this new research provides a fascinating insight into how our ancestors were able to communicate with each other, even without the use of modern technology or language. It is hoped that this new understanding will help us to better understand the history of humans, and their societies and cultures.

text: Any sensible lender will require a lean lien against your formerly-free-and-clear property, and will likely require an appraisal of the property. The lender is free to reject the deal if the house is in any way not fitting their underwriting requirements; examples of such situations would be if the house is in a flood/emergency zone, in a declining area, an unusual property (and therefore hard to compare to other properties), not in salable condition (so even if they foreclose on it they'd have a questionable ability to get their money back), and so forth. Some lenders won't accept mobile homes (manufactured housing) as collateral, for instance, and also if the lender agrees they may also require insurance on the property to be maintained so they can ensure that a terrible fate doesn't befall both properties at one time (as happens occasionally). On the downside, in my experience (in the US) lenders will often require a lower loan percentage than a comparable cash down deal. An example I encountered was that the lender would happily provide 90% loan-to-value if a cash down payment was provided, but would not go above 75% LTV if real estate was provided instead. These sort of deals are especially common in cases of new construction, where people often own the land outright and want to use it as collateral for the building of a home on that same land, but it's not uncommon in any case (just less common than cash down deals). Depending on where you live and where you want to buy vs where the property you already own is located, I'd suggest just directly talking to where you want to first consider getting a quote for financing. This is not an especially exotic transaction, so the loan officer should be able to direct you if they accept such deals and what their conditions are for such arrangements. On the upside, many lenders still treat the LTV% to calculate their rate quote the same no matter where the "down payment" is coming from, with the lower the LTV the lower the interest rate they'll be willing to quote. Some lenders might not, and some might require extra closing fees - you may need to shop around. You might also want to get a comparative quote on getting a direct mortgage on the old property and putting the cash as down payment on the new property, thus keeping the two properties legally separate and giving you some "walk away" options that aren't possible otherwise.  I'd advise you to talk with your lenders directly and shop around a few places and see how the two alternatives compare. They might be similar, or one might be a hugely better deal! Underwriting requirements can change quickly and can vary even within individual regions, so it's not really possible to say once-and-for-all which is the better way to go.
label: hc3human

text: Basically , " fog " is what happens when there 's more moisture in the air than the air can contain while remaining transparent , i.e. , there 's enough moisture in the air to push the humidity level beyond 100 % . That 's not possible , so the excess water appears as fog or condenses as dew / frost . The reason there 's fog in the morning which commonly " burns off " by mid - day is that cold air can hold less moisture than warm air , i.e. , it will take less water to reach 100 % humidity . So given a fixed amount of water in the air , you 'll start to see dew and even fog as the temperature drops , both of which will go away as the temperature rises .

In den letzten Wochen und Monaten hat der Finanzminister an konkreten Vorschlägen für ein verbessertes Regelwerk für die sogenannten ESOPs (Employee Stock Ownership Plans) gearbeitet. Nun ist es so weit, dass er seine Entwürfe vorstellt, die als Ergebnis einer eingehenden Prüfung durch seine Experten erarbeitet wurden.

Als erster Schritt beinhalten die Vorschläge Änderungen beim bisherigen Strukturmodell der ESOPs. Derzeit gibt es drei Modelle – den direkten Aktienanteil, die Mehrheitsbeteiligung und den sogenannten Trust. Der Finanzminister will nun all diese Modelle in ein einziges Modell integrieren, das als „Unified ESOPs“ bezeichnet wird. Durch die Einführung dieses einheitlichen Modells soll die Verwaltung und Verteilung von Aktienanteilen an Mitarbeiter und Angestellte deutlich vereinfacht werden.

Darüber hinaus sieht der Finanzminister vor, mehr Transparenz bei den ESOPs zu schaffen. Dazu wird es eine öffentliche Datenbank geben, in der alle Informationen über jeden einzelnen Aktienbesitzer hinterlegt sind. Der Finanzminister sieht in dieser Datenbank auch ein großes Potenzial, um auf interessante Weise den Handel mit den Aktien von Unternehmen zu fördern.

Auch der Steueraspekt spielt bei den ESOPs eine wichtige Rolle. Um diesen Aspekt zu verbessern, plant der Finanzminister, eine Verringerung der steuerlichen Belastung zu ermöglichen. Insbesondere soll die Besteuerung der Aktiengewinne und Dividenden im Vergleich zu anderen Ländern angepasst werden. Zudem sollen Steuerprivilegien bei der Anlage von ESOPs an Angestellte geschaffen werden, um kleineren Unternehmen zu helfen.

Ein weiterer Schlüsselaspekt ist die Regulierung. Der Finanzminister will ein robustes Regulierungsrahmenwerk schaffen, um dafür zu sorgen, dass ESOPs nicht von Betrügern missbraucht werden. Außerdem soll der Schutz der Rechte der Mitarbeiter und Angestellten gestärkt werden, die ESOPs halten.

Als zusätzliche Maßnahme will der Finanzminister auch den Zugang zu Finanzdienstleistungen für ESOP-Besitzer erleichtern, indem er die Kosten für den Kauf und die Verwaltung der Aktien senken wird.

Der Finanzminister hofft, dass die oben genannten Vorschläge in einigen Monaten in Kraft treten können, um den Mitarbeitern und Angestellten größeren Schutz und mehr Kontrolle über ihre ESOPs zu geben. Wenn die Gesetzesänderungen eingeführt werden, werden die ESOPs in Zukunft noch attraktiver werden, was einen weiteren Anstieg der Investitionen in ESOPs bedeuten wird.

Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, emerged from prison a hardened reformer determined to tackle poverty and inequality after serving nearly two years in jail on corruption charges.

Though Lula was released from prison in December, 2019, his time served set him on a path that profoundly reshaped the country’s politics and put the spotlight on Brazil’s extreme wealth disparities.

After winning the Workers’ Party (PT) presidential nomination in November 2020, Lula revived Brazil’s progressive spirit and hitched it to his mission of reducing poverty.

His vow to fight corporate greed and inequality, coupled with his promises of greater economic growth, resonated with the country’s working class.

Lula’s relentless advocacy for social justice and the defense of the impoverished has been carried out with a level of energy and determination that has never been seen before in Brazilian politics.

In his first year in office, Lula pushed a series of measures aimed at tackling poverty, including the provision of free school meals and healthcare access to the poor, as well as cash transfers to the unemployed. 

In addition, he launched a “social housing” initiative to provide affordable housing to low-income families.

But Lula’s greatest victory has been his fight against Brazil’s corporate elites.

He has increased taxes on the wealthy, enacted measures to boost wages for workers, and pushed for greater regulation of big businesses.

The government has also cracked down on banks and other financial institutions that have been accused of exploiting the country’s poor.

In short, Lula has been able to make sweeping changes to Brazil’s social and economic landscape.

Analysts attribute his success to a fierce determination to tackle poverty and inequality, as well as a willingness to embrace innovative solutions to address Brazil’s economic woes.

It is an agenda that is both pragmatic and progressive, and one that has not been seen in Brazil since the era of the “economic miracle” under the leadership of Fernando Henrique Cardoso in the 1990s.

In his first year in office, Lula has been able to move Brazil’s economy out of recession and restore its lost dignity.

But it is too early to tell whether Lula will be able to sustain these positive gains in the long run.

There are many challenges still to be overcome, including political infighting and economic pressures.

Nevertheless, Lula’s story stands as a testament to the power of conviction and the potential of a single individual to achieve meaningful change in a country struggling with entrenched corruption and inequality.

The former president’s determination to fight for social justice and the defense of the impoverished has earned him a place in history, and his legacy of reform and progress will be felt for years to come.

As of January 1st, 2023, employers in certain states, cities, and counties must now provide their employees with information about the range of salaries within the company. This new requirement is part of a larger trend in the United States to promote pay transparency, and ensure workers are paid fairly and equitably.

The U.S. Department of Labor, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and other government agencies have implemented this new rule in order to protect employees from unfair salary discrimination. Although the details vary depending on the jurisdiction, in general, employers must provide a list of job titles and salary ranges to employees upon request. The list must be updated at least once a year and must include job titles, base salary, overtime rate, and potential bonuses or commissions, if applicable. 

The new rule applies to employers in 21 states, including California, New York, and Illinois, plus certain cities and counties throughout the United States. It is important to note that some areas, such as the District of Columbia, have their own pay transparency requirements. 

The new law is a crucial step forward for creating more equitable pay practices in the workplace. Previously, employees were unable to compare their salaries to colleagues in similar positions and were more vulnerable to salary discrimination, especially when employers refused to provide salary information. This new law is an important step in increasing fairness and transparency in the workplace. 

Employers in the affected states, cities and counties should be aware of the new requirements and familiarize themselves with the specific rules that apply in their jurisdiction. The Department of Labor has released a handy guide to pay transparency requirements, which outlines the specifics in each area. 

In addition, employers should consider how they will communicate this information to employees and ensure that their policies are compliant with the new law. Employers should also review their pay structures and ensure that salaries are in line with the market rate for each job. This could be a great opportunity for employers to review their salary and compensation structures and ensure that their pay practices are equitable and fair. 

Pay transparency has been an important issue for decades, but the current economic climate has put a spotlight on the issue and highlighted the need for greater equity in the workplace. This new law is a crucial step forward in achieving pay equity and ensuring that workers are compensated fairly for their work. 

It is also an important reminder of the importance of pay transparency and salary equity in the workplace. Employers in the affected states, cities, and counties must be sure to comply with the new law and be aware of the implications for their business. By understanding the importance of pay transparency and taking the necessary steps to ensure fair and equitable pay, employers can create a better working environment for all.

text:
McDonald's and KFC, two of the largest fast-food chains in the world, have pulled out of Russia following a military incursion into Ukraine by Vladimir Putin's government.

The companies, part of Yum Brands, which also owns Taco Bell, announced their exit from the region on Thursday following a week of hostilities between the two nations.

The two U.S.-based companies had been operating in the region since the 1990s, with both chains proving popular with locals. But after Putin's government ordered forces into eastern Ukraine, the companies said they no longer felt comfortable operating in the region.

In a joint statement, the companies said:

"In light of the current situation in Ukraine, we have decided to close our restaurants in Russia. We are making every effort to support our staff in this difficult time and will be providing them with appropriate assistance as needed."

The statement continued: "We recognize the importance of serving customers in Russia, but the safety of our staff and customers is our priority and we believe that this is the right decision for the moment."

The move is the latest example of how businesses, particularly those based in the United States, are being forced to reconsider their presence in Russia.

In the wake of the crisis, many other companies have taken similar steps. For example, the French hotel chain Accor, which operates the Ibis chain of hotels, recently said it would suspend its operations in the region.

But while McDonald's and KFC are leaving, one U.S.-based fast-food chain is still operating in Russia — Domino's Pizza.

Domino's, which has been in the region since 2010, operates over 200 stores in the country and is one of the largest pizza chains in Russia.

It has not yet announced any plans to leave the region, but it is unclear if the company will be able to continue operating if the situation in the region continues to worsen.

Domino's did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Business Insider.

It's not just fast-food chains that have felt the fallout from the conflict. Many other companies are reconsidering their operations in the region, too.

Google, for example, recently announced it was pulling its YouTube service from Russia in response to increasing censorship in the country.

Meanwhile, Visa and MasterCard have suspended their processing of payments in the region due to sanctions imposed by the U.S.

As tensions between Russia and Ukraine continue to escalate, it seems likely that other companies could follow McDonald's and KFC and exit the region. 

It remains to be seen what will happen to the remaining companies operating in the region, including Domino's, but the current situation is making the future uncertain.

The mayor of Washington, D.C., Muriel Bowser, is calling on President Biden to end federal work-from-home policies or to create an affordable housing plan to ease the district’s rental crunch.

In a letter to Biden, Bowser wrote that “although the remote work policies implemented by the Trump Administration saved lives by helping to reduce the spread of the virus, they are also contributing to Washington, D.C.’s housing affordability crisis.”

Bowser said that the federal government should provide more options for its workers who are unable to return to their workplaces, such as offering them remote work opportunities in other parts of the country. She also suggested that the federal government could help with D.C.'s affordable housing crunch by providing incentives to developers to build housing that is more affordable.

“My administration has taken aggressive steps to increase the availability of affordable housing in the District,” Bowser wrote. “These efforts are critical to maintaining the vibrancy and economic health of the District, but they are not enough to solve our current affordability crisis.”

The mayor’s request comes as the housing situation in the city has become increasingly dire. According to the Washington Post, the number of people living in shelters in the city has nearly doubled in the past year, while the number of available rental units has decreased by 20 percent. The median rent for a two-bedroom apartment in D.C. has also skyrocketed to $2,150, a 12 percent increase from 2019.

The situation has become so dire that the D.C. Council recently approved emergency legislation that would extend the eviction moratorium until October and require landlords to give tenants 90 days’ notice before starting any eviction proceedings.

At the same time, Bowser has asked the Biden administration for $2.2 billion to support D.C.’s housing and economic development efforts. In her letter, she also asked for additional funding to expand the District’s voucher program, which helps low-income residents with rental payments, and to provide financial assistance to those struggling to pay rent during the pandemic.

In the meantime, Bowser has urged the Biden administration to continue to allow telework for federal employees, but to work with local leaders to address the challenges caused by the large influx of remote workers.

“I believe this is an issue that requires a national solution,” Bowser wrote. “We must work together to ensure that we provide sustainable housing options that are accessible to federal workers and available to our residents in all corners of the city.”

It remains to be seen whether Biden will take the mayor’s advice, but it is clear that the housing crisis in D.C. is a mounting concern and one that the city’s leaders are taking seriously. With the federal government’s help, the city’s renters may be able to find some relief soon.

: Unsere ersten sechs Monate als digitaler Nomade 

Es war nur ein Gedanke. Als mein Lebenspartner und ich Ende 2017 unsere Jobs kündigten und uns auf den Weg machten, um ein Jahr als digitale Nomaden zu reisen, hatte ich eine andere Idee. Wir hatten bereits ein Airbnb-Apartment in Thailand gebucht, aber statt einfach dorthin zu gehen, war mein Plan, auf dem Weg dorthin unser eigenes, verrücktes Projekt zu machen: den Bau eines Baumhauses in einer Baumkrone in Costa Rica.

Mein Lebenspartner war zunächst nicht ganz begeistert. Schließlich hatten wir bereits verschiedene Dinge geplant und es war nicht gerade der beste Zeitpunkt für ein solches Unterfangen. Aber ich wusste, dass ich das schaffen konnte und dass es uns helfen würde, unsere Reise zu finanzieren.

So ging es los. Als wir anfingen, begann ich, mich über Baumhäuser zu informieren. Ich las Bücher und sprach mit Experten. Ich entwarf eine einfache Zeichnung für das Haus und suchte nach Materialien und vor allem nach einem Ort, an dem wir bauen konnten. Im Januar 2018 fanden wir unseren perfekten Ort - ein paar Morgen Land in den Bergen mit einem atemberaubenden Blick.

Als nächstes mussten wir die nötigen Werkzeuge und Baumaterialien kaufen. Wir entschieden uns, möglichst viel zu recyceln, was dazu führte, dass wir einen Großteil des benötigten Holzes zusammensuchten. Wir fanden Holz aus verlassenen Gebäuden und alten Möbeln, die wir auf dem Flohmarkt kauften. Wir mieteten einen alten Traktor, um die groben Holzteile zu schneiden und entschieden uns, ein paar einfache Handwerkzeuge zu kaufen. Es war ein langsamer und langwieriger Prozess, aber schließlich hatten wir alles, was wir brauchten.

Mit unseren Werkzeugen und Materialien fuhren wir in unser Baugelände. Unsere Idee war, die Baumkrone als Grundlage für das Haus zu verwenden. Wir bauten einen stabilen Rahmen, der das Haus stützen würde, und begannen damit, das Baumhaus zu bauen. Es war anstrengend, aber auch eine der besten Erfahrungen, die wir je gemacht haben. Wir arbeiteten jeden Tag daran, das Baumhaus zu bauen. Nach zwei Monaten war es fertig und wir konnten unser Airbnb-Baumhaus in die Kette einbringen.

Es dauerte nicht lange, bis wir unsere ersten Gäste hatten. Die Nachfrage war so groß, dass wir anfingen, das Airbnb-Baumhaus als ein Stand-alone-Geschäft zu betrachten. Wir bewarben es über soziale Medien, schafften eine Website und begannen, unsere Preise zu erhöhen. Wir hatten Gäste aus aller Welt und die Einnahmen reichten aus, um unsere Reise zu finanzieren.

Es war ein unglaublicher Erfolg. Nach sechs Monaten als digitale Nomaden reisten wir weiter, aber auf einer neuen Grundlage. Wir hatten genug Geld, um

Amidst the nationwide push to end the use of cash bail, Illinois remains stuck in limbo due to a judge’s ruling. In February, the state had passed legislation that would effectively eliminate cash bail for the majority of misdemeanor and felony cases. The state followed the lead of other states, such as California and New Jersey, and aimed to reduce mass incarceration and save taxpayer money. However, in a recent ruling, Judge Matthew F. Kennelly of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois stated that the changes to the bail system are unconstitutional and go against the state’s principle of equal protection.

The legislation, known as the Pretrial Fairness Act, aimed to reform the cash bail system by essentially removing it altogether. The bill was aimed at reducing the state’s prison population by eliminating the need for cash bail. Under the act, defendants were to be released, provided they could prove they were not a danger to the public, were not a flight risk, and met certain requirements such as appearing in court or staying away from any victims. The bill also stated that each jurisdiction had the ability to develop their own pretrial evaluation system to determine who needed to post a bond. 

The proposed change has been met with some opposition, however. Those who oppose the bill argue that without cash bail, judges will no longer have the ability to hold dangerous criminals in custody. They also argue that getting rid of cash bail could have an impact on public safety and victim’s rights. On the other hand, supporters of the bill argue that cash bail has been used to oppress the poor and accused people of color for years, allowing those who are financially able to pay for their freedom. 

Despite the bill being signed into law in February, it was put on hold when Judge Kennelly ruled it was unconstitutional. In his ruling, Judge Kennelly stated that the bill violates the equal protection clause by making “arbitrary distinctions between similarly situated persons.” Specifically, Judge Kennelly noted that the proposed changes fail to recognize any difference between defendants who have higher and lower pretrial risks. He argued that it is unconstitutional to make decisions regarding bail without any consideration for the particular circumstances of each defendant. 

The Judge’s ruling has put the Pretrial Fairness Act on hold, leaving many advocates uncertain about the future of cash bail reform in Illinois. Supporters of the bill plan to continue to push for change, but in the meantime, the fate of the bill remains uncertain. Governor J.B. Pritzker plans to appeal the ruling, while state legislators are looking into finding a way to make the necessary changes to the bill to ensure it is compliant with the court’s ruling. For now, the Pretrial Fairness Act remains on hold and it is unclear when, or if, the Illinois will be able to move forward with its plans to eliminate cash bail.

Für viele Gründer ist es ein Wettrennen, ein stabiles Unternehmen aufzubauen. Doch wie wird man erfolgreich und vor allem nachhaltig? Carsten Maschmeyer, Gründer, Investor und Autor des Bestsellers „Rich Dad Poor Dad“, hat einige Tipps parat, die Gründern für das Jahr 2023 helfen könnten.

„Ich glaube, dass Erfolg im Grunde leicht zu erzielen ist, wenn man einige kluge Entscheidungen trifft und sich für die richtigen Investitionen entscheidet“, sagte Maschmeyer. „Die Schlüssel zum Erfolg sind harte Arbeit, Disziplin und Fokus. Aber es geht auch darum, Trends im Blick zu haben und kontinuierlich zu investieren, um ein erfolgreiches Unternehmen aufzubauen.“

Maschmeyer glaubt, dass Gründer ihre Investitionen in drei Bereiche aufteilen sollten. Der erste Bereich sind Start-ups, das heißt, Unternehmen, die eine neue Technologie, ein neues Produkt oder ein neues Geschäftsmodell anbieten. „Hier ist es wichtig, zu verstehen, worauf man sich einlässt, bevor man eine Investition tätigt“, sagte er. „Es ist auch wichtig, dass man sich die Zeit nimmt, die richtigen Leute kennenzulernen und die richtigen Investitionen zu machen.“

Der zweite Bereich, in den Gründer investieren sollten, sind bereits etablierte Unternehmen, die expandieren und auf neue Märkte zugreifen möchten. Hier geht es darum, sich in die bestehenden Strukturen einzuarbeiten und dann die bestmöglichen Investitionsmöglichkeiten für das Unternehmen zu finden.

Der letzte Bereich sind dezentralisierte Unternehmen, die kleine Investitionen erfordern, aber viele Möglichkeiten bieten. Dies können proprietäre Unternehmen sein, aber auch Franchise-Unternehmen oder Kooperationspartner. „Diese Unternehmen sind in vielerlei Hinsicht eine gute Investition, da sie eine sehr geringe Investition erfordern und dennoch die Chance auf ein schnelles Wachstum bieten“, sagte Maschmeyer.

Maschmeyer empfiehlt den Gründern auch, kontinuierlich in sich selbst zu investieren. „Ich denke, es ist wichtig, sich weiterzuentwickeln und das eigene Potenzial zu steigern“, sagte er. „Das kann bedeuten, dass man Zeit in die Weiterentwicklung seines Wissens investiert, beispielsweise durch Seminare oder Online-Kurse. Man sollte auch versuchen, sich immer wieder neue Fähigkeiten anzueignen, die man auf die eigene Firma übertragen kann.“

Das letzte, was Maschmeyer sagt, ist, dass Gründer nicht nur an sich selbst denken, sondern auch an die Gesellschaft als Ganzes. „Der Fokus sollte auf einer sinnvollen Unternehmensführung und gesellschaftlichen Verantwortung liegen, um die Zukunft unseres Planeten zu sichern“
label: machine

er Than We Thought. 

It was almost a decade since Akira was first released and still, fans continue to be fascinated by the movie’s iconic motorcycle, the Kaneda bike. Die-hard fans have attempted to re-create their own versions of the legendary machine, only to find out that it’s a lot harder than they expected.

With Akira’s long-awaited anime remake coming out soon, the Kaneda bike has become an even more popular subject of discussion, with many wondering if it’s possible to recreate it in real life.

However, it turns out that making your own Kaneda bike is a lot harder than it looks. That’s because the Kaneda bike isn’t just a prop — it’s a real, functioning vehicle.

To begin with, fans would have to find a vintage Suzuki GN125 motorcycle and modify it to look like the Kaneda bike. This is no easy feat, as the GN125 is no longer in production and is difficult to find in good condition. Not to mention, the modifications needed to make the bike look like the one in the movie are complex and time-consuming.

Another problem is the fact that the bike needs to be powered by two engines — one in the front and one in the rear — to emulate the real-life Kaneda bike. The engines must be highly modified and require extensive knowledge of mechanics in order to get them working. Even then, there’s no guarantee that the engines will be able to withstand the weight of the bike and its rider, let alone reach the speeds seen in the movie.

Even if fans do manage to find the right parts and get the engines to work, there’s still the issue of aesthetics. Making the bike look exactly like the one in the movie requires a lot of attention to detail, from the decals to the paint job. All of these modifications have to be carefully planned and executed, which could take a considerable amount of time and effort.

Not to mention, the most difficult part of making your own Kaneda bike is finding the right parts. The bike uses some rare and expensive components, such as the vintage GN125 frame, which can be hard to find. Plus, the complex modifications needed to get the bike working could be expensive, so the total cost of making your own Kaneda bike could be quite high.

Despite all of this, however, some die-hard fans are still determined to make their own version of the legendary machine. There are plenty of tutorials online that detail the process of building your own Kaneda bike, from finding the right parts to assembling it, so fans can still attempt to recreate the iconic bike.

Still, it’s clear that making your own Kaneda bike isn’t for the faint of heart. It requires a lot of money, time, and effort to make the bike look and function like the one in the movie, so fans should think carefully before taking on such a daunting task.

Heavy tax-loss selling weighed on stocks at the end of 2022, and some of those names could be poised for rebounds in the new year, Morgan Stanley said Thursday.

In a note to clients, strategist Michael Wilson said a large number of stocks likely sold off in December as portfolio managers scrambled to take losses before the end of the year to offset potential gains and reduce their tax liability.

The strategist identified a list of names that he believes should now be due for a rebound given the magnitude of the December sell-off.

"With the calendar now flipped to 2023 we will start to see tax-loss selling reverse, particularly for those stocks that sold off in December to the greatest degree," Wilson wrote.

The strategist expects a rebound in some financials, REITs, energy and materials stocks.

Wilson said he expects the 'golden opportunity' of the late 2022 sell-off to create attractive entry points for some of the stocks on his list, including Morgan Stanley itself.

Other stocks the strategist identified as potential winners include Anthem, J.M. Smucker, First Solar, Alcoa, Devon Energy, and the SPDR Real Estate Select Sector ETF.

"In each of these cases, we think the risk/reward is attractive," he wrote.

Wilson added that while some of these stocks may have seen a modest bounce already, he expects that they "should continue to grind higher" in the coming weeks and months.

The strategist also said that he believes the strong rise in cyclical and value stocks that began in the fourth quarter of 2022 should carry into the first quarter of 2023.

"There is still a lot to be excited about in terms of new stimulus and potential further returns to cyclical and value stocks that could still drive additional upside in stocks and other assets over the next quarter," he wrote.

In conclusion, Wilson said that investors should take advantage of the tax-loss selling rebound and look for golden opportunities to buy cyclical stocks on the dip.

"We think the rotation out of growth and into value, particularly in the more cyclical sectors, continues to be one of the dominant investment themes for the first quarter," he wrote. "We remain bullish on these 'cheap cyclicals' and recommend taking advantage of any pullbacks due to tax-loss selling."

It all started with an idea and a dream. I’d heard about people building treehouses in their backyards and thought it sounded like an interesting project. I never could have imagined it would turn into a successful business.

It was late 2018 when I first started thinking about the idea. I’d been laid off from my job and was feeling a bit down on my luck. I wanted to do something to get me out of my funk and create some extra income.

So I spent some time researching treehouse construction and found a local builder who could help. I designed a two-story treehouse with a loft and a porch, and the builder was able to bring my vision to life.

It was a great feeling seeing the finished product. I decided to turn it into an Airbnb rental, thinking it could bring in some extra income while I looked for a job.

I listed the treehouse on Airbnb and was pleasantly surprised by the response. Bookings started rolling in almost immediately, and within a few months, I was making enough money as an Airbnb host to be able to quit my job and become a full-time entrepreneur.

The process of managing the treehouse hasn’t always been easy, but the rewards have been well worth it. I’ve met so many amazing people from all over the world and had the opportunity to share my corner of the world with them. It’s been a really rewarding experience.

The treehouse has proven to be a great investment. I charge between $200 and $250 per night, depending on the season, and I’m able to manage the property on my own with very little overhead. I’ve also had a lot of repeat customers, which makes it all the more satisfying.

For anyone considering setting up their own Airbnb rental, I’d highly recommend it. There’s a lot of work involved but it can be incredibly rewarding. It’s given me the freedom to be my own boss, explore my creativity, and make a comfortable living. I couldn’t be more thrilled with how it’s turned out.

The market got off to a strong start in 2021, with all three major U.S. stock indexes posting record-breaking gains. But by the end of the year, it seemed as though the euphoria had faded. Wall Street's hope for a swift economic recovery had given way to uncertainty, as the coronavirus pandemic dragged on, taking a toll on the global economy.

Now, however, there's a renewed sense of optimism among analysts and investors. In particular, mega-cap tech stocks have been getting a lot of attention lately, with analysts bullish on the potential for these companies to drive market growth in 2021.

The renewed optimism is centered largely around the FAANG stocks - Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google - which have been among the best performing stocks over the past year. Although the stocks pulled back in the latter part of 2020, they've rallied in 2021, and some analysts expect them to continue to outperform.

The reasons for Wall Street's renewed optimism in mega-cap tech stocks are twofold. First, the companies are well-positioned to benefit from the economic recovery. As the pandemic subsides, many of the companies stand to benefit from increased consumer spending as people go out and shop again. 

In addition, many of these companies are already leaders in their respective sectors, so the increased economic activity could result in even more market share for these firms. This could lead to higher profits, which could then translate into even more stock gains for investors.

Second, the companies are in a better position to weather the storm. They have large cash reserves and highly efficient operations, so they're more likely to ride out any downturns in the economy.

Of course, it's too early to call a bull market in mega-cap tech stocks. Many analysts are taking a wait-and-see approach, as there's still some uncertainty surrounding the economic recovery and the potential for a resurgence in the virus.

But with the recent surge in share prices, the market sentiment certainly appears to be on the side of these stocks. So while it's still too early to make any definitive predictions, it looks like Wall Street's renewed optimism in mega-cap tech stocks is likely to continue in 2021.

text:
For thousands of years, Egyptians were thought to be mummifying the dead to preserve their bodies for afterlife. But, new evidence suggests that these ancient people may not have been trying to preserve bodies after death at all.

A recent study by a team of archaeologists, biologists, and historians from various universities around the world has revealed new information about the ancient practice of mummification. The team analyzed samples from over thirty mummies, which were excavated from archaeological sites in Egypt. The analysis revealed that the ancient Egyptians did not appear to be attempting to preserve the body after death. Instead, they may have been attempting to create a symbolic representation of a deceased individual that embodied the living person.

The research team found that the materials used in the mummification process, such as linen and resins, could not have been used to preserve the body. In fact, the resins and oils used in mummification would have caused decay, rather than prevented it. Furthermore, the positioning and wrapping of the mummies was found to be inconsistent with a preservation process. 

The research team also discovered evidence that ancient Egyptians were using mummification to create a symbol for the deceased individual rather than preserve the body. They found that the arrangement of the mummies was often symbolic and could represent different aspects of the deceased’s personality. In some cases, items like jewelry and amulets were placed on the body to represent their status in life. The team also found that the wrapping of the mummies was often intended to provide a protective covering, which was then adorned with religious symbols. 

The research team concluded that mummification was a symbolic and religious process, which was intended to honor the deceased and create a representation of them in the afterlife. They suggest that the practice was intended to reflect the concept of the “ka”, which is an ancient Egyptian term that refers to an individual’s life force or spirit.
