El nuevo año está a la vuelta de la esquina, lo que significa que muchas personas están tratando de encontrar una manera de deshacerse de los kilos que ha ganado durante las vacaciones.

Es cierto que la Navidad es una época para disfrutar de la comida, los dulces y los momentos de diversión con familiares y amigos. Pero una vez pasada la temporada de festividades, muchos buscan formas para adelgazar y volver a estar en forma.

Es entendible que muchos quieran recuperar su peso antes de la Navidad, pero es importante recordar que esto lleva tiempo. Si tratas de llegar a tu objetivo de adelgazamiento de manera demasiado rápida, podrías sufrir de complicaciones de salud.

Aquí te ofrecemos algunos consejos y trucos para adelgazar y volver a estar en forma después de las vacaciones.

Primero y principal, haz un seguimiento de tu dieta. Si no controlas lo que comes, puede resultar imposible alcanzar tus objetivos. Intenta mantener un diario de alimentación en el que anotes lo que comes. Esto te permitirá ver dónde estás excediendo en tu dieta y tomar las medidas necesarias para corregir tus hábitos alimenticios.

Segundo, bebe mucha agua. Cuando el cuerpo está deshidratado, tienes menos control sobre tu apetito y tus niveles de energía. Trata de beber un vaso de agua cada vez que sientas hambre. Esto te ayudará a mantener tu metabolismo activo y prevenir la acumulación de grasas.

Tercero, come de forma saludable. Trata de incorporar frutas y verduras a tu dieta y eliminar alimentos como los alimentos fritos y los alimentos procesados. Esto te ayudará a reducir tu ingesta de grasas saturadas y a obtener los nutrientes necesarios para mantener tu cuerpo saludable.

Cuarto, haz ejercicio. Para tener resultados visibles al adelgazar, debes combinar la dieta saludable con el ejercicio regular. Intenta encontrar alguna actividad física que disfrutes, como caminar, correr, andar en bicicleta, nadar o ir al gimnasio.

Quinto, prueba con algunos suplementos naturales. Los suplementos naturales pueden ser muy útiles para acelerar la pérdida de peso. Si eliges tomar un suplemento, asegúrate de seguir las instrucciones para su uso y busca el consejo de un profesional de la salud certificado antes de tomar cualquier cosa.

Sexto, duerme bien. El cuerpo humano necesita una cantidad adecuada de sueño para mantenerse saludable. La falta de sueño se asocia con el aumento de peso, así que trata de dormir entre 7 y 8 horas por noche.

Séptimo, aliméntate a intervalos regulares. Esto significa comer pequeñas porciones de comida con regularidad durante el día en lugar de grandes cantidades de comida de vez en cuando. Esto ayuda a regular el azúcar en la sangre y a aumentar el metabolismo.

Octavo, evita los alimentos con calorías vacías. Los alimentos con calorías vacías, como los refrescos y las golosinas, solo te aportan calorías sin nutrientes. Intenta evitarlos si quieres adelg

text:
The United States is facing a labor shortage, particularly in industries like construction, manufacturing, and warehousing. Employers in many states are offering higher wages and more attractive benefits, but they still can't find enough workers. At the same time, millions of workers are stuck in jobs that don't pay a living wage and offer little in terms of job security. 

So what's the solution? It starts with raising wages. 

For the last decade, the federal minimum wage has remained stuck at $7.25 an hour, the same rate it has been since 2009. In today's economy, this isn't nearly enough to make ends meet. According to the Economic Policy Institute, a family of four needs an annual income of at least $48,500 just to pay for basic necessities. To reach that level, an employee would need to make $23.40 an hour.

States have begun to take matters into their own hands, and some have gone far beyond the federal minimum wage. For example, California, Massachusetts, and Washington all have minimum wages of $12 or more, and in New York the minimum is $15. 

But in many states, the minimum wage remains stuck at $7.25 an hour. This is particularly true in states with lower overall wages, like Mississippi, Arkansas, and South Carolina. The same is true for some of the rural and small-town areas in more populous states like Missouri and Indiana.

And in even more states, the minimum wage isn't $7.25 an hour — it's lower. In Louisiana and Alabama, the minimum wage is $7.25 an hour only for those who are covered by the federal Fair Labor Standards Act. In those states, the minimum wage for some workers is actually $2.13 an hour.

And the thing is, raising wages won't just be good for workers — it will also be good for employers, who will be able to attract more workers with higher wages and better benefits. This is especially true in industries with chronic labor shortages, like hospitality, construction, and manufacturing.

The good news is that some states are taking matters into their own hands. In California, for instance, lawmakers recently passed a bill that would raise the state's minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2023. Other states are moving in the same direction, with Oregon and Illinois both introducing legislation to raise their minimum wages to $15 an hour by 2022.

But as long as the federal minimum wage remains stuck at $7.25 an hour, millions of workers in states across the country will continue to be stuck in jobs that don't pay a living wage and offer little in terms of job security. And until that happens, the labor shortage will likely continue. 

If we want to solve the labor shortage, we should start by raising wages. It's time for Congress to do the right thing and give American workers the pay they deserve.

The human body is designed to function optimally at a certain temperature range. On the other hand, when the body is too warm, the body's metabolic processes speed up and the body may become overworked, leading to feelings of discomfort and even pain.

Our body has a built-in system for regulating its temperature called thermoregulation. When the body gets too cold, our bodies naturally try to warm up by constricting blood vessels and generating heat through muscle activity, such as shivering. When the body gets too warm, our bodies naturally try to cool down by dilating blood vessels and sweating.

In general, most people find warmth to be more comfortable because the body is able to function more efficiently at a warmer temperature. However, it's important to note that both extreme cold and extreme heat can be harmful to the body and can lead to serious health problems if not properly managed.

Shares of Bed Bath & Beyond plummeted more than 30% on Wednesday after the company warned investors of potential bankruptcy.

The company had issued a statement on Tuesday saying it is “evaluating alternatives to improve its financial position and may pursue a restructuring, refinancing or other strategic alternatives,” including a bankruptcy filing.

“There can be no assurance that the Company will be able to successfully complete any such alternatives or refinancing,” the statement said.

Bed Bath & Beyond has been struggling for some time, despite efforts to revamp its brick-and-mortar stores and online presence. Last year, the company sold off its Christmas Tree Shops and Harmon stores, laid off employees and closed locations in an attempt to cut costs. The company also suffered from canceled orders and reduced foot traffic in stores due to the pandemic.

The news of potential bankruptcy sent shares of Bed Bath & Beyond down as much as 37% on Wednesday. It was the biggest one-day drop for the stock since it became a publicly traded company more than 20 years ago.

The company’s financial situation is uncertain. It had only $228 million in cash and cash equivalents as of its most recent quarterly report in November.

Some investors have blamed Bed Bath & Beyond’s management and board of directors for the company’s decline. Activist investor Legion Partners has called for the ouster of certain board members and argued that the company needs to focus on cutting costs and increasing sales rather than relying on stock buybacks and dividend payments.

The company’s chief executive, Mark Tritton, has pushed for a turnaround plan to streamline the company’s operations and increase sales. He has focused on leveraging the company’s online presence and introducing new brands.

On Wednesday, Tritton issued a statement saying, “We recognize the difficult times we are in and the challenges we are facing. We continue to take aggressive action to improve our operational and financial performance, including eliminating costs and reducing investments in non-core businesses and activities.”

He added that the company is in “close dialogue” with lenders, who are “supportive” of its plans to strengthen its balance sheet.

The company is currently in the process of evaluating “available options and actions,” but it did not provide specifics.

Analysts have warned that Bed Bath & Beyond could eventually be forced into bankruptcy if it cannot secure financing or find a buyer.

“It is too soon to tell whether the retailer will ultimately be successful in finding a financially viable path forward or if a bankruptcy filing is inevitable,” Jefferies analyst Randal Konik said in a note Wednesday.

Bed Bath & Beyond has been struggling for years, but the pandemic and the company’s financial struggles have taken their toll. The company’s stock is down more than 77% over the past year.

If Bed Bath & Beyond files for bankruptcy, it would join other retailers, such as J.C. Penney, Neiman Marcus and J. Crew, that have filed for Chapter 11 protection during the pandemic.

text: Image segmentation is the process of dividing an image into multiple segments or regions, each of which corresponds to a different object or background. It is an important task in image processing and computer vision, as it allows for the extraction of meaningful information from images and the separation of objects from their backgrounds.    There are several different approaches to image segmentation, including:    Thresholding: This is a simple but effective method of image segmentation that involves setting a threshold value for pixel intensity. Pixels that are above the threshold are assigned to one region, while pixels below the threshold are assigned to another region.    Edge detection: This method involves identifying the edges or boundaries of objects in an image. Edges are typically defined as locations where there is a significant change in pixel intensity, and can be detected using algorithms such as the Sobel operator or the Canny edge detector.    Clustering: Clustering algorithms can be used to group pixels in an image into different segments based on their colors or other features. K-means clustering is a popular method for image segmentation.    Region growing: This method involves starting with a seed point and then expanding the region to include neighboring pixels that are similar in some way, such as color or texture.    Image segmentation is used in a wide range of applications, including object recognition, medical image analysis, and autonomous vehicle navigation.

India’s finance ministry raised a windfall tax on crude, diesel, and aviation fuel prices on Thursday, introducing a special levy aimed at increasing government revenue while curbing the rise of fuel prices.

The windfall tax, which will be effective from 1 January 2024, comes as a response to the recent hikes in petrol, diesel, and aviation fuel prices in India. This levy is likely to raise additional resources for the government and provide some relief to consumers.

The Finance Ministry has said that the Windfall Tax will be calculated on the difference between the prevailing price and the base price. The base price is the price at which crude oil, diesel and aviation fuel was sold during a certain time period determined by the government. The difference between the base price and the prevailing price will be taken as the price of the windfall tax.

The tax will be applicable to sales of all fuel products, including crude oil, diesel, and aviation fuel. It is expected to raise additional resources of around Rs 1,000 crore per annum for the government.

The windfall tax comes in response to the recent rise in fuel prices in India. Petrol prices have been rising for the last two years, and diesel prices have risen sharply in the last few weeks. The rise has been attributed to rising international crude oil prices.

The windfall tax is expected to provide some relief to consumers as it will act as a dampener on the rising prices of fuel products. It is also expected to increase government revenues and help reduce the fiscal deficit.

The Windfall Tax will be applicable to all Indian companies importing crude, diesel, and aviation fuel. The tax rate has been kept high, at up to 30 percent, to ensure that any windfall gains are captured by the government.

The tax is also likely to encourage Indian companies to invest in renewable energy resources. This is in line with the government’s goal to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels and increase its use of renewable energy sources.

The windfall tax is expected to be reviewed and amended in the upcoming budget to address any issues or changes in the fuel prices. It is expected to provide some relief to the consumers and additional revenue to the government.

Overall, the imposition of the windfall tax will have a positive effect on the Indian economy as it will reduce fuel prices and increase government revenue. It is also expected to encourage Indian companies to invest in renewable energy sources.

The company also said that the layoffs will be focused on its “non-core businesses and entities,” though it did not name them.

The company said that it will incur one-time restructuring charges of up to $1 billion in connection with the cuts. The restructuring is also expected to result in unspecified cash savings and capital expenditures savings over the next three years.

In addition to the job cuts, HP will also reduce its number of entities by up to 45%, which the company said would “help improve its agility and competitiveness.”

HP said the move is part of a strategy to “improve customer experience, simplify operations, and drive long-term value creation.”

“The changes we are making are necessary to ensure that HP is a leader in its chosen markets and an employer of choice for our employees and partners,” Lores said.

The layoffs mark the latest move by HP to adjust to the changing economic landscape brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic. The company already cut jobs earlier this year, including 1,400 positions in March.

text:
Elon Reeve Musk FRS (/ˈiːlɒn/ EE-lon; born June 28, 1971) is a business magnate and investor. He is the founder, CEO and chief engineer of SpaceX; angel investor, CEO and product architect of Tesla, Inc.; owner and CEO of Twitter, Inc.; founder of The Boring Company; co-founder of Neuralink and OpenAI; and president of the philanthropic Musk Foundation. With an estimated net worth of around $139 billion as of December 23, 2022, primarily from his ownership stakes in Tesla and SpaceX, Musk is the second-wealthiest person in the world according to both the Bloomberg Billionaires Index and Forbes's real-time billionaires list.
Musk was born in Pretoria, South Africa and briefly attended at the University of Pretoria before moving to Canada at age 18, acquiring citizenship through his Canadian-born mother. Two years later, he matriculated at Queen's University and transferred to the University of Pennsylvania, where he received bachelor's degrees in economics and physics. He moved to California in 1995 to attend Stanford University. After two days, he dropped out and with his brother Kimbal, co-founded the online city guide software company Zip2. In 1999, Zip2 was acquired by Compaq for $307 million and Musk co-founded X.com, a direct bank. X.com merged with Confinity in 2000 to form PayPal, which eBay acquired for $1.5 billion in 2002.
With $175.8 million, Musk founded SpaceX in 2002, a spaceflight services company. In 2004, he was an early investor in the electric vehicle manufacturer Tesla Motors, Inc. (now Tesla, Inc.). He became its chairman and product architect, assuming the position of CEO in 2008. In 2006, he helped create SolarCity, a solar energy company that was later acquired by Tesla and became Tesla Energy. In 2015, he co-founded OpenAI, a nonprofit artificial intelligence research company. The following year, he co-founded Neuralink—a neurotechnology company developing brain–computer interfaces—and The Boring Company, a tunnel construction company. Musk has also proposed a hyperloop high-speed vactrain transportation system. In 2022, his acquisition of Twitter for $44 billion was completed. 
Musk has made controversial statements on politics and technology, particularly on Twitter, and is a polarizing figure. He has been criticized for making unscientific and misleading statements, including spreading COVID-19 misinformation. In 2018, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sued Musk for falsely tweeting that he had secured funding for a private takeover of Tesla. Musk stepped down as chairman of Tesla and paid a $20 million fine as part of a settlement agreement with the SEC.

text:
When it comes to making the most of your money, few financial moves are as impactful as saving regularly. That’s why it’s important to have a plan in place for the next time you get a raise.

As a financial planner and founder of MYRA Wealth, a financial planning firm, I’ve seen clients who can successfully grow their savings and investments when they receive a raise. Here are my top three tips for maximizing your money whenever you get a pay raise.

1. Automate your savings and investments.

If you want to make sure your raise goes to your financial goals, the best thing you can do is to set up automatic payments from your paycheck to the accounts you have set up to save and invest. You can automate your deposits to retirement accounts like 401(k)s and IRAs, as well as to other long-term investment accounts, like a taxable brokerage account.

By setting up automatic deposits, you can ensure that your raise is set aside for its intended purpose, and you won’t have to think about it or transfer the money manually. This can also make it easier to develop a habit of consistently adding to your savings and investments.

2. Make room in your budget for fun.

It’s important to save and invest a portion of your raise, but it’s equally important to give yourself room in the budget to enjoy it, too. A lot of people want to put the entire raise towards their financial goals but that’s not always realistic or necessary.

Think about using a portion of your raise to do something fun — whether that’s a weekend getaway, a class or hobby, or a new wardrobe, you can use your raise as a way to reward yourself and make your financial goals more achievable. Even small splurges here and there can give you something to look forward to, which can make saving and investing easier.

3. Use your raise to pay down debt.

Another way to make the most of your raise is to use it to pay down your debt. Having too much debt can prevent you from achieving your financial goals, so the sooner you can pay it off, the better.

If you have high-interest debt, such as credit cards or student loans, consider using a portion of your raise to make extra payments. This can help you pay down your debt faster and save money on interest over time.

Saving and investing for the future is important, but it’s also important to recognize that getting a raise is an opportunity to enjoy the present — and make progress towards your long-term goals. By using your raise strategically, you can make the most of the money you receive and enjoy the rewards now and in the future.

This can make it more difficult for your body and brain to adjust to being awake, and it can cause you to feel grumpy and have a headache.  One way to try to avoid sleep inertia is to limit your naps to 20-30 minutes, which can help you feel more alert and refreshed after you wake up. There 's a thing called gravitational sheer , where as hot liquid things cool , gravity drags the cooler particles down , stirring the substance . This promotes the formation of aluminum crystals , which is why aluminum is opaque . If you can cool aluminum without that sheer force , it will cool as an amorphous solid - a glass . And it 'll even be transparent . I 'm not talking about ALON , which is an aluminum oxide ceramic that is transparent , that 's got oxygen molecules in it and is formed under a different process to make a different lattice structure . On Monday, the Federal Trade Commission announced a proposed ban on “no-poaching agreements” between employers, arguing they are a “significant restraint of trade” that harm workers by reducing wages.

The move could have far-reaching impacts on companies in the US and help shift the balance of power back to workers, who have become increasingly disadvantaged in the face of expanding corporate power and declining labor unions.

Under the proposal, companies would no longer be allowed to sign agreements that would prevent their workers from taking jobs at competing companies. The agency estimated that lifting the restrictions could give US workers an additional $300 billion in wages each year.

“For too long, no-poaching agreements have deprived workers of the freedom to move from job to job, reducing their wages and limiting their career opportunities,” FTC Chairman Joe Simons said in a press release. “The FTC’s action today will help restore competition among employers and provide a critical opportunity for workers to improve their economic prospects.”

The proposal would prohibit companies of any size from making and enforcing “agreements not to solicit, recruit, hire, or otherwise compete for the services of each other’s employees.” This includes agreements between employers in the same industry, as well as those between companies in related industries.

The agency estimates that workers in the US currently make up to 10 percent less than they otherwise would have if these restrictive agreements were not in place. In addition, the ban would likely benefit lower-paid workers, as the agency noted that “no-poaching agreements disproportionately harm lower-paid workers, who generally have fewer job options.”

The proposal will now be subject to a 60-day public comment period before it is formally approved by the FTC. If the ban is passed, companies that violate it could face steep financial penalties, including potential civil litigation.

It remains to be seen just how effective the FTC’s proposed ban on no-poaching agreements will be in improving wages for US workers. While the agency’s proposal is certainly a step in the right direction, it’s unclear how much of an effect it will have on actual wages. That said, the proposed ban could go a long way toward restoring the balance of power between employers and employees, and the additional $300 billion in wages each year would be a welcome boon for many Americans.

A Manhattan pharmaceutical tycoon convicted of murdering his son died Thursday night shortly after the US Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor denied his request for bail.

Igor Oliver, a self-made billionaire, had been awaiting his appeal in the State Supreme Court for his convictions of first-degree murder of his son and second-degree murder of his former wife, for which he was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. The convictions had been upheld by a lower court in January.

Oliver had appealed to the US Supreme Court in late March, claiming his trial was unfair and the evidence had not been presented correctly. His attorneys argued that he had been denied due process.

Justice Sotomayor, who reviewed the case and had agreed to hear arguments in the Supreme Court on Thursday, ultimately denied his request for bail and wrote in her ruling, "The nature of the allegations and the evidence presented at trial, including multiple eyewitness accounts, present a compelling case that the defendant is a danger to the public and the court declines to grant bail.”

Oliver, 65, was a well-known philanthropist and had been a respected figure in the pharmaceutical industry for many years. He had been accused of killing his son, David, who was found dead in his Manhattan apartment in October 2018. He was also charged with killing his former wife, Mary, who was found dead in her apartment in April 2019.

Oliver had denied any involvement in either death and his attorneys argued that he had been framed by the Manhattan district attorney's office.

However, the jury found sufficient evidence to convict him of the two charges and Oliver was sentenced in November 2019.

A medical examiner's report showed that Oliver's son had died of a lethal combination of drugs and alcohol, while his former wife had died of blunt force trauma and strangulation.

Oliver was taken to a hospital shortly after his Supreme Court appeal was denied, according to court officials. He passed away in the late evening, still awaiting his appeal.

Oliver's death, combined with his convictions and sentencing, has saddened the pharmaceutical and business worlds.

"It is a tragic and heartbreaking story all around," said Miriam Stauffer, a professor at NYU's Stern School of Business and a long-time friend of Oliver's. "He was a brilliant and generous man and was respected in the industry. His death is a tragic loss, not only to the business world but to his family, who have suffered so much."

Oliver's convictions and death, while tragic, serve as a reminder of the justice system's complexity and that even the rich and powerful can face the consequences of their actions.

The GOP will now be watching closely to see whether Jordan can bridge the gap between the hardliners and moderates and unify the party ahead of the 2024 election. Bernard Kalb, the longest-serving foreign correspondent of the television age, died Thursday at the age of 100.

Kalb was best known for his decades of service covering events throughout the world for CBS, NBC, and other outlets. Born in Chicago in 1923, he was one of the first to successfully combine a print career with television broadcasting.

Kalb covered the Vietnam War from both sides, as well as the Middle East, Central America, and many other locations. He was one of the first to visit post-Mikhail Gorbachev Russia and covered the fall of the Soviet Union.

In addition to his broadcast work, he was a contributing author to several books and wrote columns for several newspapers.

Kalb was a strong believer in the importance of balanced and accurate journalism. He championed the need for foreign correspondents to have a comprehensive understanding of their areas of expertise, arguing that depth and breadth of knowledge were essential to providing a fair and balanced view of world events.

"When it comes to international reporting and international understanding, there is one thing we all need to remember," Kalb wrote in his memoir, In the Hot Seat. "The more complex the information is and the more ambiguous the judgments one needs to make, the more important it is to spend time and effort getting to know the nuances of a situation on the ground.”

Kalb was also a staunch defender of press freedom and the importance of accurate, independent journalism. He was a fierce critic of the US government's attempts to stifle the freedom of the press by enforcing oppressive regulations and using intimidation tactics, such as threats of lawsuits or criminal prosecution, to silence reporting on certain topics.

In his later years, he was a vocal advocate for the protection of journalistic sources, arguing that without the assurance of anonymity, many important stories would never be reported.

“It’s an issue of national security," he once said in an interview. "Without sources that you can protect, you can never get to the bottom of the truth."

In his long career, Kalb was the recipient of numerous awards and honors, including being inducted into the Hall of Fame of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

He was also a keen observer of the world’s problems and never shied away from taking a stand on difficult topics. His writing and analysis of the events of the day will no doubt be missed. 

Kalb is survived by his wife, Judith; their two daughters, Emily and Katherine; and their grandchildren. 

In his memoir, he wrote, “Journalism can be a very rough and ragged business but I have never regretted a single moment of it."

Indeed, despite the fast-moving pace and often arduous conditions of the international beat, Kalb remained deeply devoted to his work until the very end. He will no doubt be remembered as a giant among his contemporaries and an inspiration to many in the journalistic community.

“It’s hard out here,” said Sonya. “Living on the streets means constantly looking over your shoulder, and there’s a constant fear of being robbed or attacked. I’m always trying to find food and places to sleep. It’s exhausting.”

Another woman, Mary, said that she had been living on the streets for almost two years. Mary was determined to get back on her feet and find stable housing, but with limited resources, she was struggling to make ends meet.

“I get a few meals a day at a shelter, but it’s hard to find other help,” said Mary. “When I’m on the streets, I feel like no one sees me or cares about me. It’s like I’m invisible.”

The homeless people gathered in the park shared stories of despair, but they also spoke of hope and resilience. Many of them had started small businesses or had found employment, despite the difficult circumstances.

“I’m not a victim,” said one man. “I’m a survivor. I’ve been homeless for six years, but I refuse to give up. I’ve been able to build a successful business and I’m determined to keep pushing forward.”

In particular, the collector toy segment has been booming, with sales of action figures and other collectible toys increasing by 20 percent in 2020. Many adults are buying the same toys they had as children or making a nostalgia-driven purchase for their own children.

The growth of the toy industry has been good news for toy makers as well. Companies like Mattel and Hasbro have seen their sales grow as adults embrace the nostalgia of toys they grew up with.

In addition to toy makers, retailers are also reaping the benefits of the toy boom. Toys "R" Us, which closed its stores in 2018, was bought out by a consortium of investors and is expected to re-open its doors in 2021. The chain's relaunch could be another boon for the toy industry.

With Toys 'R' Us reopening its doors, there's an even greater opportunity to capture the nostalgia and attention of adult toy buyers."

It appears the trend of adults buying their favorite childhood toys is here to stay, and toy makers and retailers are set to benefit from the continued growth of the industry. From Barbie dolls to Lego blocks, it's clear that adults are driving the toy industry's resurgence.

text: In game theory, regret is the feeling of remorse or disappointment that a player experiences when they realize that they could have made a different decision that would have led to a better outcome. Regret is often used as a measure of the quality of a decision-making process, with decisions that result in low regret being considered to be more rational or optimal than those that result in high regret.    One common way to measure regret is to compare the outcome of a decision to the outcome that would have resulted if the player had made a different decision. For example, if a player chooses to play a certain strategy in a game and the outcome is not as good as they had hoped, they may experience regret if they realize that they could have chosen a different strategy that would have led to a better outcome.    Regret can be a useful concept in game theory because it helps to quantify the cost of making a suboptimal decision. It can also be used to analyze how a player's decision-making process changes over time, as players may learn from their mistakes and adjust their strategies to avoid experiencing regret in the future.

text: As others have pointed out, it's all about a fixed, small cost versus the potential of a large cost. If you have insurance, you know you will pay a fixed amount per month. There is a 100% probability that you will have to pay this premium. If you don't have insurance, there is a large chance that you will have no cost in any given month, and a small chance that you will have a large cost. Like my home-owners insurance costs me about $50 per month. If I didn't have insurance and my house burned down, I would be out something like $100,000. What's the chance that my house will burn down this month? Very small. But I'd rather pay $50 and not have to worry about it. On the other hand, I just bought a filing cabinet for $160 and the store offered me an "extended warranty" for something like $20 a year. What's the probability that some accident will happen that damages my filing cabinet? Pretty small. Even if it did, I think I could handle shelling out $160. I can imagine my stomach in knots and lying awake at nights worrying about the possibility of losing $100,000 or finding myself homeless. I can't imagine lying awake at nights worrying about losing $160 or being force to stuff my files under the bed. I'll take my chances. When I was young and had even less money than I have now, I bought cars that cost me a thousand dollars or. Even poor as I was, I knew that if the car was totaled I could dig up the cash to buy another. It wasn't worth paying the insurance premium. These days I'm driving a car that cost me $6,000. I have collision and comprehensive insurance, but I think it's debatable. I bought the car with cash to begin with, and if I had to I could scrape up the cash to replace it. Especially considering that my last payment for my daughter's college tuition is due next month and then that expense is gone. :-)

Shares in Tokyo, Singapore, Hong Kong and Sydney all fell, with investors looking ahead to a more mixed economic picture in the region this year.

In Tokyo, the benchmark Nikkei 225 slid 0.8%, while the broader Topix fell 0.7%. South Korea's Kospi dropped 1.3%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index declined by 0.7%, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 lost 0.5%, and Singapore's Straits Times index dropped 0.4%.

The declines come after the MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex-Japan index rose 45.3% in 2020, the most for the region since the index began tracking in 1998.

However, the surge in regional equities was countered by a dismal economic outlook, with most countries in the region still grappling with the COVID-19 crisis.

Japan was the only market in the region to end 2020 in positive territory. Investors in Tokyo were encouraged by the news that the government had approved an extra $203.7 billion stimulus package, hoping it could help bolster the country's struggling economy.

But the country remains saddled with a sluggish economy and many economists warn that a rebound may be difficult to achieve, given the extent of the COVID-19 fallout.

Across the region, the immediate outlook remains a grim one, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimating the Asia-Pacific region could experience its deepest contraction on record.

The fund expects the regional economy to contract by 1.7% this year, with output falling for an unprecedented fourth consecutive year and unemployment expected to stay elevated.

With weak economic growth expected to persist, investors in the region appear to be positioning themselves defensively. According to data from Nomura Global Markets Research, the largest inflows into Japan equities over the past two months have been into stocks with high dividend yields and lower volatility.

Meanwhile, in Singapore, stocks with low debt, low beta and high dividend yields have seen the greatest inflows.

As for the rest of the region, investors may continue to remain cautious in the near term as the coronavirus pandemic rumbles on.

Analysts are predicting that vaccine rollouts across the region could take longer than anticipated. With the duration of the pandemic still uncertain, investors are likely to remain focused on stocks with more conservative valuations, such as those with high dividend yields and low volatility.

Looking ahead, experts say that while the outlook may remain uncertain, there could be opportunities in sectors such as technology and healthcare, as well as companies that can benefit from digital transformation and structural changes in the economy.

"We expect to see opportunities in selective sectors and stocks that could benefit from economic recovery and structural reforms," said Michael Bacon, head of Asia equity research at Credit Suisse.

This shift is part of a larger effort to become a “workforce-lite” company. Starbucks plans to reduce its number of in-store baristas and other non-store personnel by 30% in the next five years. This move comes on the heels of similar moves by companies like Amazon, who recently announced plans to automate parts of its workforce.

The kiosks will allow customers to order items by scanning QR codes and paying with their phones or other digital payment methods. Starbucks also plans to use facial recognition technology to personalize customer experiences and display targeted promotions.

At the same time, the company is investing in new training programs for its employees. It recently announced a new “Starbucks Experience University”, designed to train its personnel in the latest technologies and give them the skills to better serve customers.

Analysts have praised Starbucks’s decision to focus on customer experience and digital tools, citing the potential to expand the company’s presence and customer base. “Starbucks has been a leader in customer service and digital innovation for years, and this move further cements their place as one of the most forward-thinking companies out there,” said Andy Ellwood, CEO of the market research firm BIA/Kelsey.

The company’s new strategy will likely have an impact on the wider food and beverage industry, particularly among smaller, independent operators. As Starbucks expands its footprint, other companies in the sector will have to find new ways to compete or risk being left behind.

Piet Boon en de New Range Rover

De Nederlandse ontwerper Piet Boon heeft zijn naam verbonden aan een van de meest iconische auto's ter wereld - de Range Rover. Samen met de autogigant Land Rover heeft hij de afgelopen maanden samengewerkt om een reeks op maat gemaakte Range Rovers te ontwerpen met tijdloze stijl en compromisloze luxe.

Dit is geen kleine prestatie. De Range Rover heeft een lange geschiedenis als 's werelds meest verfijnde SUV en het werd in 1970 geïntroduceerd. In de loop der jaren heeft het meerdere updates ondergaan en nu, voor de eerste keer, heeft het de genade van een tijdloze en moderne look gekregen door Piet Boon.

Voor velen is Piet Boon een synoniem geworden voor stijlvol design en de Nederlandse ontwerper heeft een naam gemaakt met zijn verfijnde en moderne benadering van woning- en interieurontwerp. Het is dan ook geen verrassing dat Land Rover hem heeft gekozen om de iconische auto te herontwerpen.

In aanloop naar het 50-jarig jubileum van de Range Rover, heeft Boon een reeks op maat gemaakte Range Rovers ontworpen met tijdloze stijl en compromisloze luxe. In zijn ontwerp staat de veelzijdige en prestatiegerichte aard van de Range Rover centraal, terwijl stijl en klasse worden versterkt door middel van hoogwaardige materialen en moderne technologie.

De auto is opgebouwd uit een prachtig ontworpen exterieur dat een behoorlijk ingetogen en tijdloze uitstraling heeft. Het ontwerp combineert klassieke stijl met moderne vormen en is geaccentueerd met zilvergrijze lijnen die het silhouet benadrukken en het geheel elegant aanvullen. Verder heeft de auto een donkerder exterieur dat door Boon is bedacht, dat het geheel een frisse, dynamische look geeft.

Interieur-wise heeft Boon de Range Rover voorzien van een luxe afwerking. Premium materialen, waaronder leer en hout, worden gebruikt om een verfijnd en geraffineerd interieur te creëren. Daarnaast heeft de auto een aantal geavanceerde technologische functies, waaronder een digitale instrumentenpaneel en een premium audiosysteem.

Het resultaat is een Range Rover die de perfecte balans weet te vinden tussen stijl en prestaties, maar die ook perfect in balans is met de geschiedenis en het legendarische karakter van de auto. Volgens Piet Boon was het doel van het project om een auto te creëren die 'modern maar nog steeds trouw is aan zijn oorsprong.'

De Range Rover met de nieuwe vormgeving van Boon is een stijlvolle en verfijnde auto die perfect past bij het beeld dat Land Rover heeft uitgestraald over de jaren. De auto is het beste van beide werelden - klassiek en modern, stijlvol en robuust. Het is een auto die klaar is om te gaan, die er stijlvol uitziet en die het beste biedt wat er beschikbaar is in de wereld van vandaag.
label: machine

text: Grammar induction is the process of automatically learning the grammar of a language from a set of examples. It is a type of machine learning task that is often used in natural language processing (NLP) to analyze and understand natural language text or speech.    In grammar induction, a model is trained on a large dataset of text written in the language of interest. The model then uses this training data to learn the rules and structure of the language, including the syntax (the way words are arranged to form phrases and sentences) and the semantics (the meaning of words and phrases). Once trained, the model can then be used to analyze new text and identify its structure and meaning.    Grammar induction is a challenging task because languages are complex and have many rules and exceptions. However, advances in machine learning techniques have made it possible to build highly accurate grammar induction models that can analyze and understand natural language with a high degree of accuracy. These models can be used in a variety of applications, such as language translation, text classification, and information extraction.

text: If you assume something , you are taking it to be true for the purposes of discussion ( assuming X = 5 solve for Y ; how would an estate be treated assuming it is subject to the Uniform Probate Code ) . There 's no pare of that assumption that posits that it 's actually * true * , just that you 're taking it as true for the moment . To presume something means that you actually suspect it 's true , but that you do n't have confirmation of yet . I presume you 're a human being , and that you 're capable of reading . Presuming is jumping the gun on something you 're pretty sure of , but not certain . Assuming is taking something as true , but without any assertion that it is . If you think about it in classic logic , an assumption is the basis of the syllogism , of deductive reasoning ( assuming all men are mortal and assuming Socrates is a man , Socrates is mortal ) . The syllogism is valid , but you 're not saying that you 've proven that all men are mortal or that Socrates is a man . The presumption is the other side , inductive reasoning , based on experience and probability . I presume my girlfriend will be calling me when she gets off work tomorrow to see if I need anything from the store .

text: In computer science, a dependency refers to the relationship between two pieces of software, where one piece of software (the dependent) relies on the other (the dependency).    For example, consider a software application that uses a database to store and retrieve data. The software application is dependent on the database, because it relies on the database to function properly. Without the database, the software application would not be able to store or retrieve data, and would not be able to perform its intended tasks.    In this context, the software application is the dependent, and the database is the dependency.    Dependencies can be managed in various ways, including through the use of dependency management tools such as Maven, Gradle, and npm. These tools help developers to specify, download, and manage the dependencies that their software relies on, making it easier to build and maintain complex software projects.

text: Sure! SWAP is a space on your computer's hard drive that is used as extra memory when your system is running low on RAM (random access memory). RAM is a type of memory that is used to store data that your computer is currently using or processing. When your computer needs more RAM to run programs, it can temporarily "swap" some of the data from RAM to the SWAP space on the hard drive. This helps the computer to keep running smoothly, even if it is low on RAM.  Imagine that you have a desk where you keep all of your important papers and projects. This desk is like your RAM. If you have a lot of papers and projects, you might need to use some other space, like a filing cabinet or a box, to store some of the papers that you are not currently using. This other space is like the SWAP space on your computer. When you need to use a paper that is in the filing cabinet or box, you can retrieve it and put it back on your desk (RAM) to work on it. This way, you have more space on your desk (RAM) to get other things done.  I hope that helps! Let me know if you have any more questions.

text: Trust is a spectrum . You 've probably also heard " full trust " or " complete trust " . Pairing either of those with " ... but verify " would be contradictory . " Trust but verify " means to not initially doubt but independently affirm the assertion . It 's very similar to giving the benefit of the doubt with the addition of independent validation . One example is how a manager can lead his team . " Trust " would be for him to assume the report one of his team members has given him satisfies the request , then " but verify " would be him glancing over the report before using it in his presentation . A lack of trust leads to micro - managing and a lack of verification lowers quality .

text: Antitrust laws are still in place today and are designed to prevent companies from becoming too powerful by prohibiting certain types of business practices that could reduce competition in a market. However, it is possible that these laws may not always be enforced as strongly as they could be, or that companies may find ways to work around them. One reason that antitrust laws might not be enforced as strictly as they could be is because enforcing them can be difficult. For example, it can be hard to prove that a company is violating antitrust laws, or to determine exactly how much power a company has in a particular market. Additionally, the political climate can play a role in how strictly antitrust laws are enforced. Another reason that antitrust laws may not always be effective is because companies can sometimes find ways to work around them. For example, a company might acquire a smaller competitor in a way that doesn't technically violate antitrust laws, but that still reduces competition in the market. Overall, the enforcement of antitrust laws and the impact they have on companies can vary over time and depend on a variety of factors.

text: Options are financial contracts that give the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specified price on or before a certain date. The holder of an option can exercise their right to buy or sell the underlying asset at any time before the option expires, as long as the option is still in the money. The expiration date is the last day on which the option can be exercised. If the option is not exercised by the expiration date, it will expire worthless.Options are typically used as a way to hedge risk or to speculate on the price movement of an underlying asset. The holder of a call option has the right to buy the underlying asset, while the holder of a put option has the right to sell the underlying asset. The underlying asset can be a variety of financial instruments, such as stocks, bonds, currencies, commodities, or futures contracts.

text:
World number one Novak Djokovic produced a masterful performance on Tuesday to outclass rising Canadian star Denis Shapovalov 6-3 6-3 in the quarter-finals of the Adelaide International and set up a semi-final showdown with Russia’s Daniil Medvedev.

The 34-year-old Serb was in his element throughout, storming out of the blocks and winning the opening set in just 34 minutes. He then broke Shapovalov’s serve in the fourth game of the second set and never looked back, eventually wrapping up the match in an hour and 14 minutes with a clinical forehand winner down the line.

Djokovic, who is seeking his third consecutive title at the tournament, was in outstanding form throughout, winning 89 percent of his first serve points and saving all three break points he faced.

Speaking after the match, Djokovic said: “I’m very happy to get through this one. I thought I played very well from the start and continued to build on that throughout the match.

“I was very precise with my groundstrokes and dictated the points for most of the match. All in all, it was a great performance.”

Djokovic’s victory was a third straight win over Shapovalov, who had previously beaten world number two Rafael Nadal in the round of 16 on Monday. The 20-year-old Canadian has been in excellent form in recent weeks, but was unable to break down Djokovic’s solid defense and was ultimately outclassed by his more experienced opponent.

The victory sets up a semi-final encounter with Medvedev, who overcame Portugal’s Joao Sousa in three sets in their quarter-final on Tuesday.

Speaking ahead of the semi-final, Djokovic said: “Daniil is a great player. We have had some close matches over the years and I’m sure this one will be no different. I’m looking forward to the challenge.”

Djokovic is the favourite to win the tournament and secure his third straight Adelaide International crown. He has an excellent record at the tournament, having won eight of the nine finals he has contested.

Should he prevail, it would be his 15th Grand Slam title and his fourth since winning the Australian Open in January 2019.

Meanwhile, Medvedev is targeting his first Adelaide International crown and his second Grand Slam title. The 24-year-old Russian is looking to build on his impressive performance at the US Open last year, where he reached the final before losing to Nadal.

The semi-final between Djokovic and Medvedev will take place on Wednesday at 7.30 pm local time.

For many companies, 2020 and 2021 were packed with major changes, massive mergers, and significant investments. These changes required PR strategy and flawless execution, a feat that wasn’t achieved without help from the top executive hires in the PR industry.

The team at PRWeek reviewed a wide range of PR agencies and corporations to identify the top 25 executive hires of the past two years. These hires reflect the growing importance of PR strategy in the changing business landscape, helping companies of all sizes navigate M&A deals and major strategic shifts in a volatile economic environment.

The first name on the list is Jennifer Montero, who was appointed as global head of public relations for Activision in December 2020. Montero, a former top-level PR executive at Microsoft, is no stranger to managing complex public relations issues, and her hire comes at a time when Activision is going through a major period of transition.

The next PR executive to join the list is Nathaniel A. Aborn, who was appointed vice president of global communications at McDonald’s in November 2020. Aborn was previously the head of global public relations at Starbucks, and his hire was widely seen as a sign of McDonald’s commitment to improving their messaging and reputation.

Another executive who made the list is Jen Golbeck, who was hired as chief communications officer at Oracle in January 2021. Golbeck brings a wealth of experience to Oracle, having spent nearly two decades in the communications industry. Her hire was especially notable because she was the first female to hold the position at the company.

In addition to the corporate hires, the list of top PR executives also includes a few agency hires. Martin Ohlson was hired as global head of brand and communications at Edelman in April 2021. Ohlson’s hire signaled Edelman’s commitment to finding creative solutions to PR challenges in the changing landscape.

The list also includes a number of individuals who were hired to lead new roles in the PR industry. Jennifer Kerr was named director of global communications at the United Nations in July 2021, while Lily Herman was named executive director of the International Public Relations Association in September 2021.

Other PR executives who made the list include Carrie Adman, who was appointed CMO of Visa in August 2021; Christina Corso, who was appointed senior director of PR at Google in May 2021; and Sonja Neuharth, who was appointed head of marketing and communications at Salesforce in April 2021.

It’s clear from this list of top executive hires that the PR industry is still booming despite economic uncertainty and the changing business landscape. Companies are investing in PR strategy and execution, and these hires will help them stay ahead of the competition and effectively manage their messaging in the years ahead.

Goldman Sachs’ year-end bonuses are set to be lower than expected, leading to a great deal of finger-pointing as to who is to blame.

The New York-based investment banking giant has long been known as a place where employees are well-compensated and hard work is rewarded. But this year, Goldman’s year-end bonuses are set to be far lower than what many employees were expecting, leading to accusations that the firm’s management was responsible for the dip in payouts.

The investment bank had already warned its employees earlier this year that its bonuses would be lower than normal due to the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. But even still, the cuts have been particularly acute, with some reports saying that some employees have had their bonuses slashed by as much as 50%.

The cause of the reduced bonuses is multifaceted. First, Goldman Sachs’ profits have taken a hit this year due to the pandemic and the economic slowdown it caused. Furthermore, Goldman Sachs has also been involved in legal proceedings regarding claims that it mismanaged employee retirement funds. While Goldman has denied these accusations, the legal battle has still had an impact on its profits and affected the size of its year-end bonuses.

However, Goldman’s employees are not the only ones pointing fingers at the firm’s management for the reduced bonuses. Some investors have accused Goldman’s top brass of focusing too heavily on short-term returns rather than long-term stability, which has led to the lower bonuses.

“Goldman’s management has allowed short-termism to take precedence over long-term sustainability,” said one Goldman shareholder. “The bonuses that Goldman’s employees receive are a reflection of this short-term thinking.”

Others have accused Goldman of hoarding cash in order to prop up its stock price, rather than investing in its employees and paying out higher bonuses. Still, other critics have said that Goldman has simply mismanaged its profits and could have paid out more generous bonuses if it had been better stewards of its money.

Goldman Sachs, for its part, has defended its actions and pointed out that the size of its year-end bonuses was in line with the industry average.

“The bonus pool is set each year after careful consideration and deliberation, and this year’s bonus pool is consistent with industry norms,” the firm said in a statement.

Despite these claims, however, Goldman’s employees are still likely to be disappointed with the size of their bonus. This is particularly true for those who were expecting large bonus payouts to compensate for the pay cuts and layoffs the firm has instituted in recent years.

The disappointment of Goldman’s employees is sure to be shared by shareholders, who will be watching closely to see how the firm performs in the future. If Goldman’s profits suffer and its bonuses remain low, then investors may start to question the management team’s strategy.

But for now, Goldman Sachs’ employees will have to cope with the reality of lower year-end bonuses and the scrutiny that comes with them.

text:
Tesla Inc.'s stock has been on a wild ride in recent years, with dramatic highs and lows. But the electric car maker's future could still be in doubt if it's valued like a traditional automaker such as Ford Motor Co. or General Motors Co., an investment chief warns.

Steve Deroian, chief investment officer of Black Mountain Capital Management, told Business Insider on Monday that Tesla's sky-high valuation could still come tumbling down if it's valued in the same way traditional automakers are.

"We see the market valuing Tesla as a technology company, which is why its price-to-earnings ratio has been so high," Deroian said. "But if you take that same valuation approach and apply it to traditional automakers, you could see Tesla's stock price fall more than 60 percent from its current level. We're already starting to see that play out a bit in the market."

Tesla's stock price has been on a roller coaster ride since it went public in 2010, reaching a high of $420 per share in June 2017 and a low of $176 per share in June 2019. The stock has more than tripled since then, reaching $580 per share at the close of trading on Monday.

The stock has been boosted in part by investor optimism about Tesla's growing electric vehicle business, as well as its potential to disrupt the traditional auto industry. But some analysts and investors say the company's current valuation is too high, and that it is being treated like a technology company when, in fact, it is still a traditional carmaker with all the risks that come with it.

In particular, Deroian noted, Tesla's current price-to-earnings ratio, a key measure of stock valuation, is much higher than that of traditional automakers such as Ford and GM. Ford's P/E ratio is 8.6, while GM's is 7.6. Tesla, however, has a P/E ratio of 116.

"If you value Tesla like you value GM or Ford, and you apply the same metrics, you could easily see Tesla's stock price fall more than 60 percent," Deroian said. "It could even fall more than that."

This doesn't necessarily mean that Tesla is a bad investment, Deroian added. Instead, it means investors should be aware of the risks of investing in the company.

"Investors need to understand that Tesla's current valuation is inflated, and that there is a possibility of a significant correction in the stock price," Deroian said. "It's important for investors to be aware of this risk and make informed decisions when investing in Tesla's stock."

He added that Tesla's long-term prospects remain bright, and that the company's electric vehicles could still revolutionize the auto industry.

"Tesla is still a game-changer, and if they can execute on their plans, they could be a major player in the future of transportation," Deroian said. Por segundo año consecutivo, el Ministerio de Hacienda y Administraciones Públicas ha decidido retrasar la obligación de los contribuyentes de informar en su declaración de la renta sobre sus saldos en criptomonedas, lo que ha sido recibido con gran alegría por los usuarios de estas divisas digitales.

Esta decisión ha sido tomada debido a la rápida evolución y adaptación del mercado de criptomonedas, lo que hace difícil establecer una legislación clara y estable para regular las mismas. Este retraso permitirá al Ministerio de Hacienda adaptar la normativa a este mercado para evitar la mala interpretación de sus normas.

A partir de este año, los contribuyentes tendrán que informar en la declaración de la renta sobre sus ganancias y pérdidas en criptomonedas. Esto significa que aquellos que hayan obtenido beneficios con su inversión en criptodivisas tendrán que hacer una declaración de los mismos y abonar el impuesto sobre el rendimiento de capital correspondiente.

Además de la obligatoriedad de declarar los beneficios, Hacienda también contempla la obligatoriedad de reportar los saldos en criptomonedas. Esto significa que aquellos que hayan realizado transacciones con criptomonedas y posean saldos en las mismas, tendrán que informar de los mismos en la declaración de la renta.

No obstante, el Ministerio de Hacienda ha decidido retrasar esta obligatoriedad hasta el año 2025. Esta decisión se ha tomado para dar tiempo al gobierno para estudiar con más detalle el funcionamiento del mercado de criptomonedas y establecer una legislación adecuada para regularlo de forma eficaz.

Por otra parte, el Ministerio también ha puesto en marcha el Registro de Monedas Digitales, un sistema informático específico para el control y registro de todas las operaciones realizadas con criptomonedas. Este sistema permitirá al gobierno conocer en todo momento el estado de los saldos en criptomonedas, así como establecer si los mismos han sido declarados correctamente.

Este registro ayudará también a combatir el fraude fiscal en este ámbito, ya que permitirá al gobierno controlar las transacciones con criptomonedas y exigir el cumplimiento de las normas establecidas por Hacienda.

La decisión de retrasar la obligatoriedad de reportar los saldos en criptomonedas ha sido bien acogida por los usuarios de estas divisas digitales, ya que les permite adaptarse a la legislación y hacer uso de ellas sin preocuparse por la obligación de declarar los saldos.

En el mercado de las criptomonedas se está experimentando un auge sin precedentes en los últimos meses, con una gran popularidad entre los inversores. Esta decisión de Hacienda le dará un respiro a los usuarios de estas divisas, permitiéndoles invertir libremente en ellas sin la preocupación de tener que cumplir con sus obligaciones fiscales.

En resumen, la decisión de Hacienda de retrasar la obligatoriedad de reportar los saldos en criptomonedas en la declaración de la renta fue una decisión muy acertada. Esta decisión proporciona a los usuarios de estas divisas digitales el tiempo suficiente para adaptarse a la legislación

text: Hello . I am a Bitcoin miner . There 's a lot of vocabulary in Bitcoins . I 'll put them in bold . * * Bitcoins * * are long hashes of random numbers and letters that computers try to guess . The blocks are collectively known as the blockchain . The * * blockchain * * contains the entire , detailed history of every transaction that has occurred in the bitcoin network between wallets , since its creation . * * Wallets * * send and recieve Bitcoins , and look like this 19UJAQMPqxDqhkppwzd1YFtfTbLiX3rjJ9 The entire network of Bitcoin miners set the * * difficulty * * , or how hard it is for a miner to guess a hash correctly , to ensure that blocks are created predictably ( about every 10 minutes ) . Each subsequent creation of blocks * * confirms * * the last block , so as to prevent double spending . A transaction of Bitcoins between wallets needs 6 confirmations in order to be considered valid . A block of 50 Bitcoins needs 120 confirmations in order to be considered valid . text:
Morbi bridge collapse: Indian family lost 12 members in the Gujarat disaster

Morbi, Gujarat: Early Sunday morning, a tragedy struck the small town of Morbi in the Indian state of Gujarat when a bridge connecting the old town with the new residential and commercial development collapsed, killing 12 people and injuring several others. According to local police, the victims were members of a single family and have been identified as Ashok Patel (45), Rajshree Patel (40), their son Raj (10), daughters Priya (8) and Nisha (5). Their son's wife Heena (22), her brother Sanjay (25), their children Yuvraj (2) and Chetiya (5 months old) and four other members of the family were also killed in the accident.

At around 4:30 am on Sunday, the Morbi bridge - which is about 200 metres long and 7 metres high - suddenly gave way, plunging the victims and debris into the river below. Some eyewitnesses reported hearing a loud bang before the bridge suddenly caved in. The bridge collapse occurred during peak traffic hours and dozens of vehicles, including two buses, were on it at the time of the accident.

Rescue teams arrived at the scene of the accident within minutes and immediately began the arduous task of searching for survivors. Unfortunately, none were found. Witnesses on the scene reported that the bridge had begun to wobble before it collapsed and that there were warnings that the structure was unsafe.

The chief engineer of Gujarat’s Public Works Department, Pankaj Khandelwal, announced that a team of engineers had been dispatched to examine the structural integrity of the bridge and determine the cause of the collapse.

The Gujarat government has declared a three-day state mourning in memory of the deceased. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has also expressed his condolences to the families of the victims and offered financial assistance.

The tragedy has been met with much grief and sorrow in the local community. Most of the victims’ family members lived close by and many of them have been rendered homeless due to the disaster. Local NGOs and other organizations have come together to provide assistance to those affected. 

The incident has sparked a debate about the safety of bridges in India, with many criticizing the government for failing to adequately inspect and maintain bridges across the country. Activists have called for more stringent regulations to ensure the safety of bridges, especially those in rural areas. 

Many residents have accused the authorities of neglecting to repair or upgrade the bridge despite knowing it was in a poor state. Local police have launched an investigation into the incident and have questioned several government officials in relation to the tragedy.

The tragedy of the Morbi bridge collapse highlights the need for greater investment in infrastructure and stricter safety regulations for bridges in India. It serves as a reminder of the importance of building resilient structures and of the tragic consequences when these are not adequately maintained.

Cheap television prices seem to be a blessing for consumers, but a new report shows that there’s a hidden cost: increasing energy use and carbon dioxide emissions.

As televisions get cheaper and more feature-filled, they’re also getting bigger and bigger. But, size isn’t the only factor that’s changing. According to a new report from the World Resources Institute (WRI), the quality and efficiency of TVs is changing as well—and not for the better.

The report shows that many of the new TVs flooding the market are significantly less efficient than the models that were available a few years ago. This is due, in part, to their increased size and extra features, but also because of cost cutting measures that are reducing the efficiency of the televisions themselves.

For instance, the report found that many of the most popular new TVs now use around 80% more power than their counterparts from a few years ago. This isn’t just a problem for consumers’ wallets—it’s a big environmental issue as well.

According to the report, energy use from televisions has increased by 57% globally between 2015 and 2020. And, as the TVs get bigger and more feature-filled, this trend is likely to continue. By 2030, the report estimates that the energy used by TVs could rise by as much as 70%.

This increase in energy use will have a direct impact on the environment. By 2030, the report estimates that the energy used by televisions will account for 5% of global electricity consumption, as well as 6% of global carbon dioxide emissions. This means that if no action is taken, the global CO2 emissions from TVs could double between now and then.

So, what can be done to reduce the environmental impact of TVs?

The WRI report offers several suggestions, including the implementation of government standards that require the use of more efficient technology and the offering of incentives to encourage the adoption of efficient televisions. It also recommends that manufacturers focus on improving the efficiency of their TVs in order to reduce their carbon footprint.

Of course, consumers can also play a role in reducing the environmental impact of their TVs by being mindful of energy efficiency when shopping for a new television. Before you buy, it’s important to research the energy ratings of different models and select one that has a good rating.

Another way to reduce the environmental impact of your TV is to avoid buying a bigger model than you need. Many people think that a larger TV will provide them with a better viewing experience, but this isn’t necessarily the case. A larger TV will use more energy and generate more emissions than a smaller one.

Ultimately, cheap TVs may seem like a great deal for consumers, but the hidden cost of their energy use and emissions is something we all need to be aware of. By taking steps to reduce the environmental impact of TVs, we can all help to create a more sustainable future.

text: It's definitely annoying, but it's not necessarily false advertising. There is no rule or law that says they have to fix a pricing error at all, let alone within a certain period of time. Unfortunately they have no obligation to do business with you unless they take (and keep) your money. If they canceled the order and returned your money you have no binding agreement with them.  On top of that, in the US... 'misleading advertising' usually refers to "Any advertising or promotion that misrepresents the nature, characteristics, qualities or geographic origin of goods, services or commercial activities" (Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1125(a)). The main criteria that they evaluate before taking legal action is whether or not someone has suffered harm or loss due to the reliance on the bad information. But you're in Europe. The EU ideas behind misleading advertising tend to focus a lot more on comparing one product to someone else's and making subjective claims or false promises. Pricing does come up, but still, you need to have an ability to prove that you suffered harm or a loss from the business' actions.  Even if you were able to prove that, to force the business to change its price catalog, you would need to go through legal proceedings, demonstrate the harm that you've sustained, and then have a judge decide in your favor and order the supplier to comply. My guess is that it's just not worth it for you, but you haven't specified if this is just an annoying shoe-shopping experience or if you are regularly experiencing bait-and-switch tactics from a supplier that is a crucial part of a business operation.  If it's the former, just like a physical shop reserves the right to kick you out if you're not behaving, (but usually doesn't because they'd like to keep you as a customer), an online shop can update its prices whenever they like. They can change their prices too, and cancel orders.  If it's the latter, then start putting together some documentation on how many times this has happened and how it has damaged your business. But before you get on the warpath I would recommend you look for another place to buy whatever you have in mind, or else try a pound of sugar in your approach to this supplier... My own business experience has shown that can go a lot way in figuring out a mutually beneficial resolution. If you want to see a bit more...  Here is the EU Justice Commission's website on false advertising, Here is a PDF leaflet from the UK Office of Fair Trading that spells out what is explicitly not allowed from a business by way of advertising & business practices.

text: A share buyback, also known as a share repurchase, is when a company buys back its own shares from shareholders. This can happen for a variety of reasons. One reason a company might do a share buyback is to reduce the number of shares outstanding. This can increase the value of the remaining shares because there is a smaller supply of them. For example, if a company has 100 shares outstanding and buys back 10 of them, the remaining 90 shares will represent a larger percentage of the company. As a result, the value of each share may go up. Another reason a company might do a share buyback is to use its excess cash. If a company has a lot of money that it is not using for other purposes, it may decide to buy back some of its shares as a way to return value to shareholders. Finally, a company might do a share buyback as a way to signal to the market that it believes its shares are undervalued. By buying back its own shares, the company is showing that it believes they are a good investment and that it is confident in the future of the business. Overall, a share buyback can be a way for a company to use its excess cash, increase the value of its remaining shares, and signal confidence in its own stock.

"It has been the greatest honor of my life to serve the people of Michigan and to fight for our state’s families," Stabenow said in a statement. "I am deeply grateful for the trust Michigan voters have placed in me over the years, and I’m proud of the progress we’ve made together."

Stabenow is the longest-serving woman in the Senate's history, first elected in 2000 and re-elected in 2006, 2012, and 2018. She served as the Senate's Budget Committee Chairwoman from 2013 until 2019 and is a member of the Senate's Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry.

"I am grateful for the incredible colleagues I have had the privilege of serving with in the Senate for more than two decades, including my current and past Michigan delegation colleagues,” Stabenow said. “I have been honored to lead on many groundbreaking initiatives that have improved the lives of so many Michigan families."

"I hope Michigan will send another progressive, fighting Democrat to the Senate who will help build on the strong momentum created over the past two decades," Stabenow said in her announcement.

Stabenow is the latest in a string of veteran lawmakers who are not seeking reelection in 2024. Other Senate incumbents to step aside include Republican Senators Richard Shelby of Alabama, Chuck Grassley of Iowa, Pat Roberts of Kansas and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.

Stabenow did not elaborate on her plans after leaving the Senate, other than saying she would “explore new opportunities to serve our state and our nation.”

text: Nobody knows for certain . We know what their basic properties are , but there 's still some disagreement about what they actually might be . I 'll try to summarise the current most - accepted idea , though . A quasar is essentially an incredibly powerful radio and X - ray transmitter . When I say " incredibly powerful " we 're talking numbers that are literally astronomical , and which boggle the mind -- the amount of energy being put out by quasars can be billions or even trillions of times the output of our Sun . The first astronomers to detect quasar signals were so shocked by these numbers that they assumed they 'd made mistakes in their calculations . But today the figures are accepted , and astronomers and physicists now have a plausible idea for what might provide such astonishing sources of power . They believe that a quasar is , basically , a supermassive black hole . That 's a black hole which has the mass of hundreds of millions or even billions of times that of our Sun . As with all black holes , other stellar objects will be in orbit around it , and when the orbiting stars , gas and dust start to get closer to the black hole they start orbiting faster , and faster , and faster . As they approach the black hole itself they heat up to temperatures of tens of millions of degrees , and the hotter things are the more energy they radiate . It 's believed that the energy we detect as quasars is essentially the signature of these supermassive black holes consuming the stars in the centres of the galaxies in which they 're found .
