text: For simplicity, let's start by just considering cash back. In general, cash back from credit cards for personal use is not taxable, but for business use it is taxable (sort of, I'll explain later). The reason is most personal purchases are made with after tax dollars; you typically aren't deducting the cost of what you purchased from your personal income, so if you purchase something that costs $100 and you receive $2 back from the CC company, effectively you have paid $98 for that item but that wouldn't affect your tax bill. However, since businesses typically deduct most expenses, that same $100 deduction would have only been a $98 deduction for business tax purposes, so in this case the $2 should be accounted for. Note, you should not consider that $2 as income though; that would artificially inflate your revenue. It should be treated as a negative expense, similar to how you would handle returning an item you purchased and receiving a CC refund. Now for your specific questions: Part 1: As a small business owner, I wish to attend an annual seminar to improve my business. I have enough credit card reward points to cover the airfare, hotel, and rental car. Will those expenses still be deductible at the value displayed on the receipt? Effectively no, these expenses are not deductible. If you deduct them they will be completely counter-acted by the "refund" you receive for the payments. Part 2: Does it matter if those points are accrued on my personal credit card, rather than a business credit card? This is where it gets hairy. Suppose your company policy is that employees make purchases with their own personal credit cards and submit receipts for reimbursement. In this case the employer can simply reimburse and would not know or care if the employee is racking up rewards/points/cashback. The trick is, as the employee, you must always purchase business related items normally so you have receipts to show, and if you receive cashback on the side there seems to be a "don't ask, don't tell" rule that the IRS is OK with. It works the same way with heavy business travelers and airline miles- the free vacations those users get as perks are not treated as taxable income. However, I would not go out of my way to abuse this "loophole". Typically, things like travel (airfare, hotel, car rental, meals) are expected. But I wouldn't go purchase 100 company laptops on your personal card and ask the company to reimburse you. The company should purchase those 100 laptops on a company card and effectively reduce the sale price by the cashback received. (Or more realistically, negotiate a better discount with your account rep and just cut them a check.) Part 3: Would there be any difference between credit card points and brand-loyalty points? If the rental car were paid for with points earned directly on the rental car company's loyalty system (not a CC), would that yield a different result? There is no difference. Perhaps the simplest way to think about this is you can only deduct an expense that you actually incur. In other words, the expense should show up on a bank or CC statement. This is why when you volunteer and work 10 hours for a charity, you can't call that a "donation" of any amount of money because there is no actual payment made that would show up on a bank statement. Instead you could have billed the charity for your 10 hours of work, and then turned around and donated that same amount back to them, but it ends up being a wash.

It was only a matter of time until tech giant Salesforce announced a cost-cutting plan in the wake of an economic downturn.

The San Francisco-based cloud computing giant has been one of the most impressive stock performers of the past decade. But with the global economy in a deep and prolonged slump, Salesforce has decided it is time to shore up its balance sheet.

The company said it will cut about $1 billion in operating expenses over the next two years. As part of the plan, Salesforce will reduce its workforce by 1,000, or about 6 percent of its total headcount. In addition, it plans to reduce executive pay and tighten operating costs.

The news sent shares of Salesforce soaring 4 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday. The company's market value is now above $117 billion.

Salesforce said the cost-cutting measure was not just necessary, but long overdue.

"We have been in an unsustainable economic situation for the past few years, and the pandemic has only exacerbated the situation," Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff said in a statement. "It is no secret that we have not been as prudent with our expenses as we could have been, and this plan will put us in a much better position going forward."

The cost-cutting plan includes a $250 million reduction in corporate and administrative costs and a $750 million reduction in research and development expenses. Salesforce also said it will reduce executive pay, freezing base salaries for all executives for the rest of this fiscal year, and making it more difficult for them to receive bonuses or stock options.

The company will also be restructuring its workforce, reducing employee headcount by 1,000 and focusing its resources on the core areas of growth. Salesforce said it will also be shifting to an "all-remote" work model to save costs on office space and related expenses.

The company's move comes as other tech companies have made similar announcements. Microsoft and Amazon recently announced their own cost-cutting plans, and Apple is expected to follow suit soon.

The tech sector is one of the few bright spots in the economy, and companies are looking for ways to save money and stay competitive. Salesforce's move to shore up its balance sheet is a much-needed and welcome step for the sector.

While the news is welcomed by investors, analysts caution that there may be more pain to come for the sector as the pandemic continues to put pressure on the global economy. Einstein had lots of great quotes about the idea of time and our perception of it . My favorite : “ When you are courting a nice girl an hour seems like a second . text:
Mehr als 80 Prozent der Deutschen befürchten eine eskalierende globale Konfliktlage, das Ausbleiben einer nachhaltigen Energielösung und eine erhöhte finanzielle Belastung, die Einkommen und Lebensstandard nachhaltig beeinträchtigen kann. Dies sind die wichtigsten Herausforderungen, denen sich Deutschland in der aktuellen geopolitischen Lage gegenübersieht, und laut einer jüngsten Umfrage der Bertelsmann Stiftung sind sie die größten Sorgen der Deutschen für das Jahr 2023.

Der erste Punkt, den die mehr als 2.000 Menschen im Alter zwischen 18 und 70 Jahren in der Umfrage ansprachen, war Krieg: Laut dem Bericht fürchten 82 Prozent der Befragten eine weltweite Zunahme von militärischen Konflikten und Kriegen, die sich negativ auf den Handel und den Wirtschaftsstandort Deutschland auswirken könnten. In dem Bericht heißt es: "Kriege bedrohen nicht nur Menschenrechte, sondern auch die deutschen Interessen, da ihre Auswirkungen sich direkt auf den Wirtschaftsstandort Deutschland auswirken."

Ein weiteres Anliegen waren Energieprobleme und Energieversorgung. Laut dem Bericht fürchten 70 Prozent der Befragten, dass sich das globale Klima dramatisch verschlechtern könnte, wenn sich die Energieversorgung nicht grundlegend ändert. Die Menschen sind besorgt, dass die Energiegewinnung auf der Basis fossiler Brennstoffe nicht nachhaltig ist und dass die globale Erderwärmung auch direkte Auswirkungen auf die Lebensräume und die Artenvielfalt haben wird.

Schließlich waren 76 Prozent der Befragten der Meinung, dass sich die finanzielle Belastung des durchschnittlichen Haushalts in den nächsten fünf Jahren erhöhen wird, insbesondere aufgrund der anhaltenden Wirtschaftskrise, die infolge der Corona-Pandemie aufgetreten ist. Viele Befragte erwähnten, dass die steigenden Kosten für Lebensmittel, Miete und Versicherungen die finanzielle Belastung erhöhen und den Deutschen die Möglichkeit nehmen, in ihren Lebensstandard zu investieren.

Diese Ergebnisse sind laut Richard Black, dem leitenden Autor des Berichts, ein alarmierender Hinweis auf das wachsende Unbehagen und den steigenden Druck auf die deutsche Wirtschaft und die Regierung, sich auf die bevorstehenden Herausforderungen vorzubereiten.

"In den letzten zehn Jahren ist die globale und europäische Lage durch eine Vielzahl von Krisen erschüttert worden, und es sieht so aus, als sei es nur eine Frage der Zeit, bis der nächste große Ereignis kommt", sagte Black. "Deutschland muss daher auf seine Nachbarn, seinen Handelspartnern und auf die Welt ein waches Auge werfen und sowohl Prävention als auch Entscheidungsfindung auf ein höheres Niveau heben, um sicherzustellen, dass wir den Herausforderungen von heute auf möglichst effektive Weise be

Today, ride-hailing giant Lyft announced it has cut 13 percent of its workforce as part of a restructuring of the company. The cut includes 774 employees across its corporate offices, engineering, product and marketing departments, as well as its autonomous vehicle efforts.

The layoffs come after a year of tremendous disruption to the ride-hailing industry, due to the pandemic. Though the company has seen a rebound in ride bookings in recent months, the pandemic has affected the company’s bottom line significantly.

In a letter to employees, CEO Logan Green said the restructuring was necessary in order to “ensure our long-term success and accelerate our growth”.

“We have made the difficult decision to reduce our workforce as we reset our resources and restructure our teams to better align with our new mission,” Green said in the letter. “This was an incredibly hard decision, but one that we believe is necessary to ensure our long-term success and accelerate our growth.”

The move follows the company’s decision to close its autonomous vehicle division in July, which resulted in the loss of around 100 jobs. As part of the restructuring, Lyft is also closing its corporate offices in London and Tokyo and shifting its technology resources to its San Francisco hub.

The layoffs come as Lyft continues to grapple with the economic downturn caused by the pandemic. Though ridership levels have been climbing for months, the company’s overall revenue fell by more than 70 percent in the second quarter of this year, according to the company’s most recent earnings report.

The move is expected to save the company more than $100 million over the next year.

Despite the layoffs, Lyft said it is continuing to invest in innovation and expansion, with a focus on bike-sharing, scooter-rental and other mobility options. The company also said it is working on a new mobile app and launching several new products in the coming months.

“We have grown tremendously since our launch and will continue to stay focused on what’s important: making sure our riders and drivers have the best experience, and that our employees are supported in all ways as we work together to build the transportation network of the future,” Green said.

The layoffs represent a tough period for Lyft, as the pandemic has put a strain on the company’s finances. However, the restructuring is expected to help the company emerge from the pandemic in a better position.

For those affected by the layoffs, the company said it is providing severance packages, outplacement services, and healthcare benefits. The company is also helping employees transition to new roles within the company, either at its San Francisco headquarters or elsewhere.

The pandemic has caused unprecedented disruption for ride-hailing companies. But with today’s restructuring, Lyft is aiming to ensure that it emerges from the crisis in a stronger position.

The first full moon of 2021 is set to be a showstopper.

The January full moon, also known as a wolf moon, is set to appear in the night sky on Saturday and will be visible around the world. It's the first full moon of 2021 and will be visible to the naked eye, so don’t miss it.

The full moon is the point in the moon's orbit where the lunar orb is visible in its entirety. Though the exact time of the full moon is 5:30 p.m. ET on Saturday, it will look full on the evenings of January 8 and 9, according to the Old Farmer's Almanac.

“In 2021, the Moon is considered full for about three days, from the evening of Friday, Jan. 8 to the evening of Monday, Jan. 11,” the almanac said.

The January full moon is a good way to kick off the new year, and it has some big meaning to it. It's known as the Wolf Moon, but has had a few other nicknames, including the Old Moon, Ice Moon and the Snow Moon.

The Wolf Moon name is said to come from early Native Americans, since this was the time of year when wolves would howl, according to The Farmer’s Almanac. The Moon was seen as a way to mark the passing of the seasons in a calendar year and honor how long winter had been. The names are still used today in modern lunar calendars.

The Wolf Moon will look just like the full moons we saw throughout 2020. Though the Moon may look large and bright at first sight, it's just an optical illusion. A 2018 study published in The Astrophysical Journal by experts from the U.S. Naval Research Lab found that when the Moon is near the horizon, it seems larger and brighter than when it is high in the sky.

No special equipment is needed to see the Moon Saturday night. But if you want to get a closer look, a telescope or binoculars will make the Moon look extra large, and a filter will give a better view of its surface.

The full Moon will help create a few beautiful opportunities for stargazers and photographers looking to capture a picture or two.

The full Moon will pair with the bright winter stars, creating a dramatic image that won't soon be forgotten. 

The next full moon, known as the Snow Moon, will appear February 11.

So get your cameras ready, take a moment to appreciate the beauty of the sky, and get ready to marvel at the Wolf Moon this weekend.

For years, gay media personality Jay Valle has been openly and proudly advocating for the LGBTQ community, but recently he's been dealing with a very different kind of struggle.

Valle, who was the first openly gay meteorologist in the U.S. and currently hosts the SiriusXM show "The Gay Agenda," has become the target of trolls who are exploiting his openness to do things like make fake dating profiles in his name.

"I've been dealing with this for quite a while now," Valle told NBC Out in a recent interview. "It's just sad and so disheartening to think that someone would want to capitalize on your openness and use it as a weapon against you."

Valle first noticed the problem in February when a person claiming to be a fan said he had seen a dating profile with Valle's picture and information. Valle says he was the victim of what he calls "catfishing," a term commonly used to describe someone using a fake online profile to deceive someone else into thinking they are talking to a real person.

"After that I started to get more messages from other people saying they saw my pictures on different websites, as well as people trying to friend me on various apps claiming to be me," Valle said.

Valle says he quickly realized that the problem was much bigger than he originally thought and that he was dealing with an organized effort to exploit his openness and public profile.

"I think these predators were trying to use my platform to reach vulnerable people," he said.

Valle decided to take action and reported the fake profiles to the websites they were posted on. He also filed a police report and contacted the FBI.

"I wanted to take legal action because I don't want anyone else to go through what I did," Valle said.

Valle is still dealing with the aftermath of the attacks and says he's become more wary of what he posts online.

"I'm more careful about what I put out there, not only for myself but for the people who look up to me," he said.

Valle also says the experience has made him even more passionate about advocating for the LGBTQ community.

"This whole experience has made me stronger, not only for myself but for the community," he said. "I'm even more dedicated to using my platform to lift up the voices of others and bring attention to the many issues we face."

Valle has also used his platform to spread awareness about the dangers of online predators and encourages others to do the same.

"We need to talk about this because it can happen to anyone," he said. "It's important to remember that we are strong, resilient and powerful. We must never forget to use that strength to fight back against hatred and exploitation."

text: Any defect in the bloodstream is called an embolism - defect meaning anything that is in the bloodstream that is n't blood . When the defect is air , it is called an air embolism . You suppose the first ' question ' in our chain : how does the air get there in the first place . The usual candidates are medical procedures , though major injury to a blood vessel can have the same impact . Obviously , an injection is a medical procedure . Most medical procedures with a few exceptions involve the ' return ' side of the vascular system , ie the veins - which is by design , and has a lot of positive side effects for an AE . The effect of an AE depends on where in the circulatory system it occurs . If , as we 've indicated , the embolism occurs in a vein , it will be transmitted to the heart - specifically the right Atrium . The air will then be passed by the pumping action of the atrium into the right ventricle . This is the first place where a serious problem can occur . If the quantity of air present is enough to displace a ' large volume of blood ' - about 100 mL - then the ventricle may become partially or totally obstructed , which would prevent the movement of blood in the body , and lead to death . If there is * not * enough air to occlude the ventricle , the air will be pumped to the lungs where it has the potential to escape the body through the same process that all other blood gases do . If the AE begins in the arterial part of the vascular system , the problem can be much more serious as it can block the flow of blood to a major organ or system ( eg , the brain or heart ) . The reason this can occur in the arteries but not the veins is that the arteries only ' narrow ' in the direction of the flow of blood , and veins only ' widen . ' An AE in an artery would behave exactly as any other arterial blockage , and would lead to an infarction . Now , the blood is full of dissolved gases all the time ( that 's its primary purpose after all ) - so there is an extent to which it can handle this problem . The blood has a limited capacity to dissolve air within itself , and given time the air in blood will dissolve ( assuming it does not kill the patient first ) . So a ' very small amount ' would likely be either dissolved before anything of significance happened , or be expelled through the lungs . A larger amount could pose a more serious threat , depending on precisely how large the embolism is , and where it took place . This problem is something that is experienced by divers ( associated with decompression sickness ) - but in reverse . Gases that are dissolved in the blood under pressure come out of suspension when the pressure is decreases , causing an air embolus . Interestingly , one of the treatments for an AE is a hyperbaric chamber - basically ' playing back ' the conditions of decompression sickness in reverse .

text: Rent seeking is a term used in economics and political science to describe the use of resources to try to obtain economic gain without creating any new wealth. It is often associated with attempts to use political influence or other non-productive activities to shape government policy or regulations in a way that benefits a particular group or individual. In Nigeria, rent seeking may take many forms, such as lobbying for government contracts, using connections to obtain favorable treatment or regulation, or using political power to shape policies that benefit a particular group or individual. Imagine a group of people who want to build a new amusement park in a certain area. They might try to use their political connections or financial resources to influence the government to give them special treatment, such as tax breaks or exclusive access to land, in order to make it easier for them to build the park. This would be an example of rent seeking, because the group is trying to use their resources to obtain economic gain without creating any new wealth. Overall, rent seeking is generally considered to be harmful to society, because it can lead to policies that are not in the best interests of the general public and can create inequality.

text: Imagine baseball . Only instead of a diamond , home and first base are one long stripe on the grass ( called a * pitch * ) , and when you hit the ball away , you run back and forth between them . Each time you touch home or first base ( called a * crease * ) , you get 1 point ( called a * run * ) . But when you go up to bat , there 's already a batter ( batsman ) on first base . When you start running to first , * he * starts running to home . Then , if you think you can make it again , you swap , and swap again . Whoever 's at home base when the ball is returned to the shortstop ( wicketkeeper ) will bat next , and this continues until he 's out , and one of his teammates takes his place . Behind the batter ( batsman ) is a little structure made of four sticks stuck in the ground , called the wicket . The pitcher ( bowler ) is n't trying to get three strikes , he 's trying to knock that structure over . If he does , you 're out . After the pitcher / bowler has bowled 6 times , he 's swapped for one of his teammates . This is called an * over * . The pendulum will continue to swing in the same direction, but the Earth's rotation causes the pendulum to appear to change direction.

text:
California snowpack off to one of its best starts in decades

As winter takes hold in California, a heartening report released today reveals that the state’s snowpack is off to one of its best starts in decades.

The statewide average of the Sierra snowpack, which supplies much of the state’s water supply, was nearly 180% of the season’s average as of Dec. 11, according to the California Department of Water Resources. That’s the second highest level since 2000, when water officials began tracking the data.

“This strong start to the snowpack season is good news,” said Mark Cowin, director of the Department of Water Resources. “The late arrival of a wet November helped us jumpstart the season and put us in a much better position heading into the end of the year.”

The snowpack—the amount of water content found in the snow—acts as a natural reservoir for the state, with some areas getting more than 80% of their water supply from melted snow.

The early snowfall brought some of the most welcome news for the state in an otherwise difficult year. Californians have spent most of 2020 battling some of the most destructive wildfires in state history, which together burned nearly 8 million acres. Now, a good snowpack could go a long way toward helping alleviate some of the associated strain on water supplies.

“The snowpack is a critical source of fresh water for the California economy,” said Cowin. “We need more precipitation to sustain our snowpack and build on this strong start.”

The unusually wet November in California resulted in the snowpack's overall performance. A recent storm even brought significant snowfall to Southern California, prompting some to pull out their snow boots and sleds.

The state’s mountain ranges have experienced similarly increased snow levels, with many showing unusually high levels for this time of year. For example, the Mount Shasta area was at about twice its normal snowpack level as of Dec. 11.

But the data show that weather patterns in California can be unpredictable. While wetter-than-normal weather is in the forecast for January, the season could still turn to the dry side.

So the early snowpack performance is no guarantee that water supplies will remain high throughout the coming year. “We should not be lulled into a false sense of security,” said Cowin.

Ultimately, California’s water supplies depend on an array of factors, including snowpack, reservoir levels and water conservation measures.

“We’re working hard to ensure that communities throughout the state can access the water they need to remain healthy and prosperous,” said Cowin. “We’re grateful for the snowfall and encourage everyone to continue to do their part in conserving water.”

text:
For many people, the new year is a time to make resolutions and set goals to improve their lifestyle and health. One popular resolution is to participate in a “dry January”—abstaining from alcohol for the first month of the year.

But if you’re not ready to commit to an entire month of sobriety, it’s OK. You can still take small steps to cut back on alcohol throughout the year and reap the associated health benefits.

It’s not just about following a trend; cutting back on alcohol comes with numerous health benefits. Those who consume lower amounts of alcohol, or no alcohol at all, have a lower risk of liver disease, certain types of cancer, heart attack and stroke. They are also more likely to have better sleep, more energy and a stronger immune system. 

If you’re looking to cut back on your alcohol consumption, here are five tips to help you get started.

Tip 1: Track your drinking

Start by tracking your drinking habits. At the end of the day, take note of what and how much you’ve consumed. This can help you understand your triggers and form a better understanding of your alcohol consumption. Also, it helps to stay on top of your daily allowance, if you have set one for yourself.

Tip 2: Take more “sober days”

Once you have a better understanding of your drinking habits, aim to set aside one or two days each week where you don’t drink. Doing this can help you feel more in control of your consumption and can potentially improve your overall health. You may even find that you begin to prefer these alcohol-free days.

Tip 3: Say “no”

Socializing often involves drinking, so it can be difficult to say “no” when offered a glass of alcohol. Remember, you are the only one who can make decisions on your behalf—including those related to drinking. If you’re offered a drink, you can politely decline and offer an alternative suggestion.

Tip 4: Be mindful

When you do choose to drink, it’s important to be mindful of your consumption. Slow down and drink water in between alcoholic beverages to stay hydrated and limit your intake. Also, drink slowly and consciously, and stop when you feel buzzed or have had enough.

Tip 5: Practice moderation

Moderation is key when it comes to alcohol consumption. Set limits for yourself and keep to them. As you get better at tracking your drinking habits, set goals for yourself and don’t exceed them.

Ultimately, whatever your goals may be, taking small steps to reduce your alcohol consumption can lead to immense benefits. Taking a “dry January” any time of the year, or any other month, can help you gain control and improve your health.

text: Because the rotor disc ( plane the main rotors travel in ) of a helicopter is n't fixed . How a helicopter maneuvers in the fore and aft , left and right directions is by tilting that disc ( plane of rotating blades ) in the direction you want to travel . Most helicopter rotors have a wide range of motion . With the helicopter on the ground , and the collective neutral ( blades tilted so they are n't providing lift ) you can articulate the disc down to head chopping height pretty easily . This is why you never approach a ' turning ' helicopter without the pilot signalling , so they have positive control of the cyclic in a neutral ( level ) position . Actually , depending on the terrain , you may have to tilt the disc away from loading and unloading passengers so they can safely get in and out . A good gust can tilt the disc in random directions if you are n't actively on the cyclic , which you always should be if your bird is turning . On a frigid December night, nearly a hundred Pilsen residents turned out to protest the city’s plans to increase property taxes and accelerate gentrification in the historically Latino neighborhood.

The protest began around 5pm, with dozens of local residents, community activists and organizers marching from the National Museum of Mexican Art to the site of the proposed new development, a multi-million dollar condominium complex that is slated to replace a number of homes currently occupied by low-income families.

The protesters carried signs that read “Our Home, Not Their Profit” and “Pilsen is for Everyone” as they marched along 18th Street, chanting and waving to residents of the neighborhood.

The mood was passionate and determined, with many protesters talking about their family’s history in the neighborhood. “My family’s been living here for generations,” said María Martinez, a local activist. “My grandmother moved here from Mexico in the 1940s, and we’ve been living here ever since.”

The protest was organized by two local organizations, Pilsen Alliance and SOMOS Pilsen, in response to the city’s plan to increase property taxes in the neighborhood. The organizations have long argued that such hikes will make it impossible for many low-income families to stay in the neighborhood, and accelerate the gentrification process that has been ongoing in Pilsen since the mid-1990s.

“Pilsen is home to many working class, immigrant families,” said Benjamín Muñoz, director of Pilsen Alliance. “We’ve seen too many families forced out of their homes due to gentrification, and this plan would only accelerate that process. We’re here to let the city know that this is our home and we won’t stand for it.”

The protesters marched around the condominium development, stopping occasionally to listen to organizers’ speeches and chants. Some local business owners and residents opened their windows and balconies to join the protest, while others stopped in the streets to watch.

“It’s important to be out here and show the city we’re not going to take this lying down,” said Sandra Cervantes, a local resident. “We’re going to keep fighting until we have a solution that works for everyone, not just the developers.”

The march concluded with a rally in front of the proposed condominium complex, with organizers reading demands for the city to scrap the proposal and to invest in initiatives that benefit current residents, like rent control and more affordable housing.

The protest ended after nightfall, but not without the promise of continued pressure from the community. “This is just the beginning,” said Muñoz. “We’re not going to stop until we get what we want, and that’s a Pilsen that’s for everyone.”

text: In accrual-based accounting, prepaid rent refers to the payment of rent in advance for a period of time beyond the current accounting period. When a company pays rent in advance, it is recorded as a prepaid expense on the balance sheet. This means that the full amount of the prepaid rent is not recognized as an expense in the current period, but rather is recognized as an expense in future periods as the company uses the rented property.For example, if a company pays $12,000 in rent for a year in advance, but the accounting period is only for three months, the company would record $3,000 as an expense in the current period (1/4 of the total prepaid rent) and the remaining $9,000 as a prepaid expense on the balance sheet. In the following three months, the company would recognize another $3,000 of the prepaid rent as an expense, and so on until the full amount of the prepaid rent has been recognized as an expense over the course of the year.Prepaid rent is a useful way for companies to manage their cash flow and to ensure that they have the use of the rented property for a specific period of time. It is important for companies to track prepaid expenses and to recognize them as expenses in the appropriate accounting periods to ensure that their financial statements accurately reflect the company's financial performance.

Every year, the World Happiness Report ranks 156 countries according to their overall happiness levels. In 2021, Finland was ranked the happiest country in the world, and has held this spot for the past four years.

As a psychology expert living in Finland, I’ve seen firsthand how the culture, environment, and lifestyle of this Nordic nation contribute to its inhabitants’ joy and contentment. I believe that some of the behaviors we don’t engage in as Finns are an integral part of our country’s culture of happiness.

Here are three things Finns never do, which I believe make a significant contribution to our ranking as the happiest nation in the world.

1. We don’t compare ourselves to others

Finns are a self-assured and independent nation. We don’t feel the need to compare ourselves to our neighbors, colleagues, and friends to assess our worth. We believe that everyone has their own unique talents, abilities, and contributions to offer, and we respect and value each other for them.

We don’t measure our own lives by someone else’s successes, or feel inadequate when others do better than us. We support and motivate one another, not compete with or criticize each other. This sense of collective encouragement results in healthier relationships and encourages a sense of security and self-confidence.

2. We don’t feel the need to constantly busy ourselves

In Finland, it is quite common to find people sitting quietly in cafes or parks, enjoying a cup of coffee or a scenic view. We are a nation of people who enjoy taking moments to relax, reflect, and appreciate the beauty around us.

We don’t feel the need to always be doing something. We recognize the importance of rest and relaxation, and make it an integral part of our lives. As such, Finns tend to be more present and appreciative of life, more mindful of our surroundings, and more content with what we have.

3. We don’t fall into the trap of working for external validation

Many people today find their self-worth in external validation, such as wealth, status, and material possessions. This can often lead to feelings of discontent, stress, and unhappiness.

In Finland, we strive to find our worth in more meaningful pursuits. We prioritize relationships, leisure activities, and inner fulfillment rather than a perceived societal ideal.

We recognize that in the grand scheme of things, most material possessions and social statuses are relatively insignificant. We feel a sense of satisfaction and purpose in our everyday lives, not just in accomplishments that are “impressive”.

In conclusion, as the happiest country in the world, Finland has a lot of lessons to offer when it comes to well-being. By not constantly comparing ourselves to others, taking moments to relax, and finding our worth in meaningful activities, we cultivate an environment of contentment and satisfaction. We can all take something from this example, no matter what country we live in.

Google AdWords and Google Ads are advertising platforms that allow businesses to place ads on Google and its advertising network. The main difference between the two is that AdWords is a pay-per-click (PPC) advertising platform, which means that businesses only pay when someone clicks on their ad, while Google Ads is a more general advertising platform that includes PPC advertising as well as other types of advertising such as display advertising and video advertising.

Here's a simple example to help explain the difference:

Imagine you own a bakery and you want to advertise your delicious cookies online. You could use Google AdWords to create an ad that appears when someone searches for "best cookies in town" on Google. When someone sees your ad and clicks on it, they will be taken to your website, and you will be charged a small fee.

On the other hand, if you wanted to use Google Ads to advertise your cookies, you could create an ad that appears on other websites that are part of Google's advertising network. For example, your ad could appear on a food blog that someone is reading, or it could appear as a banner ad at the top of a website. In this case, you would be charged based on how many times your ad is shown (impressions) or how many times it is clicked (clicks).

Both AdWords and Google Ads can be useful for businesses looking to advertise online, but the choice between the two will depend on your specific advertising goals and budget.

It was with a heavy heart that CNN's African Division announced on December 3rd, 2022, the passing of Gary Strieker, a veteran producer, journalist, and executive who helped establish CNN's presence in Africa.

He was considered a titan of the network's early days in Africa and will forever be remembered for his contributions to the industry.

"Today, the team of African Division of CNN is deeply saddened to announce the passing of our beloved colleague and mentor, Gary Strieker," the network said in a statement.

"Gary had a long and distinguished career in journalism and production, having established and grown CNN's African Division in the late 1990s.

He was responsible for launching the first international bureau in Kenya, and over the years, he continually supported and inspired the many journalists who he mentored throughout Africa.

He will be dearly missed by all of us at CNN and we extend our deepest sympathies and thoughts to Gary's family and friends."

Strieker first arrived in Africa in 1996, joining a small team of ambitious reporters and editors who worked tirelessly to make CNN's African presence a reality. He was one of the earliest pioneers of the network's African Division, helping to nurture and expand its presence across the continent and beyond.

He produced some of the network's most important documentaries, including an in-depth series on the conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo and a critically acclaimed documentary about the historic elections in Ghana.

In addition, he produced and hosted dozens of programs and documentaries across the continent, covering a range of topics from health and education to social and economic issues.

His work was recognized around the world and he was awarded two Emmy awards, two Peabody awards and several other prestigious awards throughout his career.

Strieker had a deep love and appreciation for the people and culture of Africa, and it was evident in his work. He devoted his career to shining a light on the issues that most affected its people.

He also dedicated much of his energy to connecting people across the continent with the resources they needed to make their lives better.

He worked with countless organizations and charities to make sure that communities had access to education, healthcare, and other essential services.

"Gary's devotion to giving voice to those without one, to amplifying the issues that matter most to the African continent, and to helping the continent realize its potential will forever be remembered," the network added in a statement.

"We are deeply grateful for Gary's contributions and for his passion for the African continent. He was an inspirational leader and mentor for so many here at CNN. He will be dearly missed."

Strieker is survived by his wife, daughter, and a granddaughter. The funeral is being planned for a later date.

CNN African Division will be holding a memorial service in his honor in early January to celebrate his life, legacy, and extraordinary contributions to journalism and media in Africa.

This past year has been one of the most profitable years for investors in recent memory. Wall Street saw some incredible highs and lows during the year and investors were the main beneficiaries.

As we look back on the year, let’s take a look at some of the biggest winners and losers in the stock market during 2022.

The Winners

One of the biggest winners of the year was Tesla, Inc. (TSLA). The electric vehicle maker’s stock soared almost 250% in the 12 months ended December 29. CEO Elon Musk’s decision to go all-in on Tesla’s electric car strategy, alongside the success of its solar and energy storage products, proved to be a winning combination.

Apple (AAPL) was another major winner of the year, rising close to 180% in 2022. The tech giant’s increased focus on services, such as Apple TV+, Apple Music, and Apple Care, alongside the success of its flagship products, were major contributing factors.

Cryptocurrencies were also big winners in 2022. The total market capitalization of all cryptocurrencies surged more than 300%, with Bitcoin (BTC) leading the way. Bitcoin’s performance was fueled by institutional demand and optimism that cryptocurrencies could become a safe haven asset class.

The Losers

Oil stocks were some of the biggest losers in the stock market during 2022. Companies such as ExxonMobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and Schlumberger (SLB) saw their stock prices fall more than 40% as demand for energy waned and oil prices declined.

Retail stocks were also hit hard in the past year. Companies such as Macy’s (M) and Kohl’s (KSS) saw their stock prices fall by more than 25% amid the pandemic-induced recession. The exodus of brick-and-mortar stores to the digital space, as well as customers’ increased shift to online shopping, weighed on the sector.

Finally, travel stocks were among the biggest losers of the year. Airlines, cruise ships, and hotel companies saw their stock prices fall by more than 50% as demand for travel dried up amid the pandemic. Many companies were forced to resort to mass layoffs and restructuring in order to weather the storm.

Conclusion

It has been a wild ride in the stock market this year. Despite the massive pullback in oil stocks and retail stocks, investors have generally done well. With any luck, the market will continue to rebound next year and investors will be rewarded for their risk-taking.

Ukraine Rings in the New Year Under Russian Attack

The New Year has begun in Ukraine, but while the country is hoping for a better 2021, it will also begin the year under a prolonged attack from its neighbor and former superpower, Russia.

Russian aggression against Ukraine has been ongoing since 2014, when Russia annexed Crimea and began a war in eastern Ukraine. This has included the build-up of troops and armaments along Ukraine's borders, regular provocations by Russian forces, cyber-attacks, and recently, the release of captured Ukrainian sailors, who had been in Russian custody since a 2018 incident in the Black Sea.

In response to the aggression, Ukraine has implemented a number of reforms to strengthen its security and promote its efforts towards European integration. It has also sought international support for its defensive efforts, although Russia has shown little sign of relenting in its campaign.

The past year saw little progress in resolving the conflict, with both sides unwilling to make any concessions. With the Biden administration set to take office in Washington, however, there is some hope that the US will be more willing to assist in resolving the crisis.

Meanwhile, Ukrainians are preparing to face another year of uncertainty, while they wait and see what the New Year brings. For now, they will continue to do what they can to prepare for the coming year, and hope that 2021 will bring some progress towards peace.

For many Ukrainians, the start of the New Year marks the continuation of a conflict that has already dragged on for too long. As they prepare to face yet another year under Russian attack, Ukrainians hope that the coming months will bring an end to the conflict, and a chance for peace and stability in the region.

The Ukrainian government has sought to use 2021 as an opportunity for reform and renewal, including increasing security measures, improving infrastructure, and fostering closer ties with the West. However, these efforts could be in vain unless Russian aggression is addressed.

Fortunately, there are signs that the international community is willing to step up its support for Ukraine. The US and European Union have imposed sanctions on Russia and have provided military assistance, while the UK and other nations have offered diplomatic support.

These measures have not been enough to end the conflict, but they have provided Ukraine with a valuable source of support. As the international community rallies around Ukraine, it is hoped that 2021 will bring the necessary diplomatic progress to bring an end to the crisis.

Ultimately, however, it will be up to the Ukrainian people to determine the course of the conflict. As they prepare to face another year under Russian attack, Ukrainians must continue to unite against the aggression, and remain hopeful that 2021 will bring progress towards peace.

This would be its worst quarterly performance since the fourth quarter of 2016, when the tech giant reported operating profit of 6.6 trillion won.

The grim earnings forecast comes as the memory chip market, one of Samsung’s most profitable businesses, has been plunged into chaos by a steep decline in prices due to oversupply.

The price of NAND flash memory, one of Samsung’s main products, has dropped around 40 percent since last October as the industry has been hit by a wave of oversupply.

In the fourth quarter, the prices of NAND flash memory chips fell 15 percent from the previous quarter, the worst quarterly decline since 2013, according to research firm DRAMeXchange.

The steep drop in prices has been difficult for Samsung and its competitors to manage, with the South Korean tech giant posting its first profit decline in two years in the third quarter.

text: P stands for " polnomial " . A P problem is one that a computer can solve " quickly " , which is to say , there 's a particular limit to the amount of calculations the computer has to perform to solve the problem . NP stands for " nondeterministic polynomial " . It means that the computer can * check * a result in polynomial time , even if it ca n't necessarily find that result from scratch at a reasonable speed . Think of it like doing a jigsaw : If you want to do a 1,000,000 piece jigsaw , it 'll take you a while . If someone says they 've solved a 1,000,000 piece jigsaw , all they have to do is show you the completed picture , which will take a second or two . Obviously all P problems are also NP , because if you can solve something from scratch quickly you can just do that to check it . The big question is : Are there NP problems which are not also P ? ( The experts believe there are , and they 're pretty sure that a particular class of NP problems called " NP - complete problems " are not P , but they 're not sure . )

text:
Finnish people are often called the happiest people in the world. According to the World Happiness Report 2019, Finland is the happiest nation on the planet. Of course, this designation doesn’t guarantee individual happiness, as there are always people who feel unhappy or troubled. But it does mean that Finland has a solid foundation of well-being, one that has been established through collective effort and investment in the public good.

As a psychologist in Finland, I’ve seen firsthand how our government, culture, and habits help us to remain happy. As a result, I’ve identified three things that Finnish people rarely do, and which play an important role in why Finland is so happy.

First, Finns rarely do anything to keep up with the Joneses. Here in Finland, we don’t measure success and happiness in material possessions like cars, clothing, or other things people tend to buy to show off their wealth. In our country, it’s common to find people who are highly educated and successful without having a lot of things. We appreciate quality and craftsmanship, but we don’t feel the need to constantly buy the latest gadgets or newest clothes. As a result, there is little stress and pressure to keep up with the Joneses.

Second, Finnish people rarely take things too seriously. One of the common characteristics of happy people is their ability to laugh at themselves and their own mistakes. People in Finland are good at doing that. We don’t take life too seriously, and this helps us stay in high spirits and focus on the positive aspects of life.

Third, Finns rarely obsess over status. As a nation, we don’t have a strong hierarchical structure in our culture. It’s rare to see people trying to achieve status or recognition through money or material possessions. Instead, we have a deep respect for knowledge and experience, regardless of where it comes from. This attitude helps us to be more accepting and open to different opinions, and it helps to keep our society egalitarian and non-competitive.

These three habits—not keeping up with the Joneses, not taking things too seriously, and not obsessing over status—all play a major role in why Finland is consistently one of the happiest countries in the world. We don’t waste time competing with each other and trying to prove ourselves. Instead, we focus on living our lives with contentment, and it is this sense of contentment that makes us so happy. So if you want to be happy like a Finn, start by implementing these three habits into your life.

text: Inverse problems are problems in which the goal is to determine some property or properties of an object or system from observations or measurements of another related property or properties. Inverse problems often arise in science and engineering, where they are used to infer information about the internal structure, composition, or behavior of an object or system from external observations or measurements.    For example, in geophysics, inverse problems are used to infer the composition and structure of the Earth's interior from measurements of its gravitational and magnetic fields. In medical imaging, inverse problems are used to reconstruct images of internal organs or tissues from measurements taken by imaging modalities such as CT scans or MRI. In electrical engineering, inverse problems are used to determine the electrical properties of materials or devices from measurements of their electrical response.    Solving inverse problems typically requires the use of mathematical and statistical techniques to analyze the data and make inferences about the underlying object or system. These techniques may include optimization algorithms, machine learning algorithms, and statistical models, among others.

(Harrisburg, PA) Pennsylvania Sen. Bob Casey has announced he has been diagnosed with prostate cancer.

The senator made the announcement on Tuesday morning in a press conference from his office in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.

“I’m here today to share with you some important news: I’ve been diagnosed with prostate cancer,” the 62-year-old senator said. “I am facing this diagnosis head on. I’m confident in my team of doctors and intend to take their advice so that I can come out of this battle in the best health possible.”

Casey, a Democrat who was first elected in 2006, said he is currently going through tests and will determine a course of treatment soon.

He said he was speaking publicly about his diagnosis to raise awareness about prostate cancer, and the importance of regular screenings.

“I want to be open and honest about my own experience so that others will be encouraged to get regular screenings,” Casey said. “Early detection and treatment are key in fighting this disease.”

Casey also thanked his constituents for their support, and said he intends to keep representing Pennsylvania in the Senate.

“I want to make one thing clear: I’m still here to fight for the people of Pennsylvania,” Casey said. “I plan to serve in the Senate as long as I’m able. I look forward to continuing to work on behalf of the people of Pennsylvania.”

The senator is no stranger to health issues. In January 2018, he was hospitalized for chest pain and released after undergoing a procedure to determine the cause. Last June, Casey revealed he had diabetes, and had been managing it with diet and exercise for years.

According to the National Cancer Institute, an estimated 191,930 men in the US were diagnosed with prostate cancer in 2019, and 33,330 men died from it.

The institute says prostate cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer in men other than skin cancer, and it is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in men.

It is believed to be caused by genetic factors, family history and lifestyle. The disease often has no symptoms in the early stages and is usually detected through a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test or a digital rectal exam.

In his remarks Tuesday, Casey encouraged men over the age of 50 — particularly those at high risk — to talk to their doctors about getting the necessary screenings.

“I want to urge all of my fellow Pennsylvanians to take their health seriously and make sure they’re getting regular checkups,” Casey said. “The earlier you detect this disease, the better your chances for a successful outcome. I’m optimistic about my own future.”

Casey’s prognosis and course of treatment are expected to be determined in the coming weeks. His office has said he will provide updates on his condition when appropriate.

Back in 2020, when the world was still normal, Blizzard Entertainment released its first major update for Overwatch 2, allowing players to play as characters from Greek mythology, introducing what would become known as ‘The Gods of War.’ Now, three years later, these characters have become the stuff of legend and their influence can still be felt throughout the game.

The characters, which include iconic figures like Hades, Zeus and Athena, are intended to represent the pinnacle of the game, providing the most challenge and entertainment to those skilled enough to take on their powers. At the same time, the characters are also being used in an innovative new way that rewards the most successful players with a unique kind of immortality.

Blizzard’s concept is simple: as players become increasingly skilled and move up the ranks in Overwatch 2, they will eventually reach the point where they are able to gain access to the powers of the Greek gods. At this point, their character model will change and will be immediately identifiable by other players. The character model will even be immortalized in the game’s Hall of Heroes, with players’ names and faces forever etched into the history of the game.

The concept isn’t just a way for Blizzard to reward the best players and create memorable characters; it’s also an incredibly clever way to tie in real-world personalities with the game. Fans of the game will recognize some of the characters’ faces and associate them with their favorite players and personalities in the scene. This opens the door for all sorts of exciting cross-promotional opportunities and collaborations between Blizzard, content creators, and streamers.

At this point, it’s unclear just how far the character models and Hall of Heroes will be taken, but it’s clear that Overwatch 2 is continuing to push the boundaries of what’s possible in the world of competitive gaming. By introducing a feature that immortalizes and rewards top players, Blizzard has given gamers something to strive for and a way to feel connected to the game, even after they leave the competitive scene.

While the gods of Olympus may only exist in the digital realm, their presence in the game will help ensure that those who embody their legacy and achieve greatness in Overwatch 2 will be remembered for years to come. Overwatch 2 has undoubtedly improved on its predecessor in many ways, and this latest addition is one more way that Blizzard is keeping the game alive and constantly innovating.

text: Is your name on the title at all? You may have (slightly) more leverage in that case, but co-signing any loans is not a good idea, even for a friend or relative. As this article notes: Generally, co-signing refers to financing, not ownership. If the   primary accountholder fails to make payments on the loan or the retail   installment sales contract (a type of auto financing dealers sell),   the co-signer is responsible for those payments, or their credit will   suffer. Even if the co-signer makes the payments, they’re still not   the owner if their name isn’t on the title. The Consumer Finance Protection Bureau (CFPB) notes: If you co-sign a loan, you are legally obligated to repay the loan in   full. Co-signing a loan does not mean serving as a character reference   for someone else.  When you co-sign, you promise to pay the loan yourself. It means that   you risk having to repay any missed payments immediately. If the   borrower defaults on the loan, the creditor can use the same   collection methods against you that can be used against the borrower   such as demanding that you repay the entire loan yourself, suing you,   and garnishing your wages or bank accounts after a judgment. Your   credit score(s) may be impacted by any late payments or defaults. Co-signing an auto loan does not mean you have any right to the   vehicle, it just means that you have agreed to become obligated to   repay the amount of the loan. So make sure you can afford to pay this   debt if the borrower cannot. Per this article and this loan.com article, options to remove your name from co-signing include: If you're name isn't on the title, you'll have to convince your ex-boyfriend and the bank to have you removed as the co-signer, but from your brief description above, it doesn't seem that your ex is going to be cooperative. Unfortunately, as the co-signer and guarantor of the loan, you're legally responsible for making the payments if he doesn't. Not making the payments could ruin your credit as well. One final option to consider is bankruptcy. Bankruptcy is a drastic option, and you'll have to weigh whether the disruption to your credit and financial life will be worth it versus repaying the balance of that auto loan. Per this post: Another not so pretty option is bankruptcy. This is an extreme route,   and in some instances may not even guarantee a name-removal from the   loan. Your best bet is to contact a lawyer or other source of legal help to review your options on how to proceed with this issue.

text:
January 4th 2023 marked a momentous occasion for both children and parents alike as the unpredictable winter weather combined with a diligent effort from both groups of folks, enabled the childhood tradition of a snow day to once again take center stage.

For parents, the joy of a snow day was both a novelty and a welcome respite from the monotony of everyday life. From a parent’s perspective, there was no greater treat than watching the excitement that radiated from their children, eager to get out in the snow and explore the winter wonderland around them.

For children, a snow day was a special event that brought out the creativity and enthusiasm they had been pent up in classrooms throughout the winter months. With snowball fights and snow angels, sledding down hills and hot chocolate after coming inside to warm up, a snow day was something to look forward to during the coldest months of the year.

But over the past few decades, the frequency of snow days had diminished drastically. Blame it on global warming, blame it on the warmer winters, but snow days were becoming a thing of the past. The weather seemed too erratic and the snow too sparse to induce the legendary wintry days off from school.

That all changed, however, when the resourceful and optimistic minds of kids got to work. With ingenuity and creativity, children from all over the world began to concoct their own methods of making it “snow” for a day, which often involved kids making snowmen or sledding down large piles of fluffed-up snowballs.

This simple, yet effective, experiment was a way for the kids to bring snow days back in a way that was enjoyable, meaningful, and accessible. For many, it became a new family activity, one that brought everyone in the family closer together as they gathered up supplies and worked to construct their own miniature winter paradise.

The best part was that any day of the year had the potential to become a snow day, regardless of the actual outdoor temperature. Kids embraced the idea of making it snow on demand, and soon it became the new way of experiencing snow days.

Snow days in this new format had just as much fun and excitement as a real snow day. Kids ran around with glee, made snow forts, and built snowmen. They ran up and down hills and threw snowballs at each other. And parents participated, making the most of the day, by helping to build snowmen and doing whatever it took to make the day a special event.

The snow days of old had found new life in the fresh eyes and creative minds of the younger generations, who refused to let it go and disappeared from winters everywhere. Now, families can gather together to bring the old tradition back in a way that is sure to make them smile and bring the wonder back to wintertime.

In 2023, couples around the world are struggling to go on first dates. It’s not because they can’t find someone they’re interested in; it’s because of the crippling inflation rates that have left many people unable to afford a dinner out.

The global economy has been suffering from high inflation rates for many years, and it’s only getting worse. As governments around the world have had to borrow heavily to pay for things like stimulus packages and fighting the pandemic, the money supply has grown, leading to prices rising even faster than wages. This has been especially hard on those in the lower income brackets, who have seen their purchasing power diminish significantly.

This has had a direct effect on the restaurant industry, which has been a major part of the economy for decades. As people struggle to make ends meet, they are less likely to spend money on a romantic dinner. Restaurants are also trying to compete with the plethora of online delivery services, which can be much more affordable. 

The trend has been especially pronounced in the United States, where inflation has been higher than in most other developed nations. A 2020 survey of diners in the U.S. found that more than two-thirds of them had reduced their spending on meals out over the past five years due to increasing prices.

This has caused many restaurants to re-evaluate their pricing strategies, as they are finding that they can’t always charge the prices they used to. In some cases, restaurants have started to offer specials or discounts to make their prices more competitive. While this can help make eating out a little bit more affordable, it isn’t enough for many people who are already struggling to make ends meet.

The long-term effects of this trend could be significant for the restaurant industry, as it could lead to a reduction in the number of restaurants in certain areas or a decrease in the number of people going out to eat. This could also have implications for the entire economy, as restaurants are a major job provider and contribute a significant amount to GDP.

It’s clear that something needs to be done to address the issue of inflation. In the meantime, those looking to go on a first date may want to consider more affordable options, like going to a local park or having a picnic. While it may not be as romantic as a fancy dinner, it’s certainly more feasible in this economic climate.

text: As an example , after WWI Germany was charged with billions of dollars of war - related damages in the meetings at Versailles . They , of course , did n't have the money to pay all those debts having just lost an expensive war . So , they turn to the richest country in the world at the time , America . America lends Germany the money it needs , who then pays it back to Britain and France . At that point , it works much like a personal debt to a bank does , of course with international trade laws in effect . Nowadays , with America being trillions of dollars in debt , it ca n't just borrow that much from any country on Earth . In this example , however , the other countries America is indebted to do n't have much power over them like a single person would to a bank . So , America just continues to print more and more money annually and has a budget set to pay its debts . But , with the debt ceiling being raised and more and more money being borrowed , it seems at this point America is not paying off its debts anytime soon . And , to explain the actual process of transferring money , obviously trillions or even billions of dollars is too much to simply write a check for or open a bank account . From what I understand , a lot of the debt is repaid through promised investments and selling of assets , in some cases . The two countries in question will come to an agreement on what kind of value they can offer through any number of ways , and that value is subtracted from the debt - to - be - repayed . TL;DR - If they can , a country will borrow the money from another , if they ca n't , it will simply take much longer to introduce the money needed into their economy . A physical or even digital transfer of money does not happen , but rather a promise that the country in debt will provide , in some way , the value of the debt to the debtor country .

text: If the stock is below its purchase price, there is no way to exit the position immediately without taking losses. Since presumably you had Good Reasons for buying that stock that haven't changed overnight, what you should probably do is just hold it and wait for the stock to come back up. Otherwise you're putting yourself into an ongoing pattern of "buy high, sell low", which is precisely what you don't want to do. If you actually agree with the market that you made a mistake and believe that the stock will not recover any part of the loss quickly (and indeed will continue going down), you could sell immediately and take your losses rather than waiting and possibly taking more losses. Of course if the stock DOES recover you've made the wrong bet. There are conditions under which the pros will use futures to buffer a swing. But that's essentially a side bet, and what it saves you has to be balanced against what it costs you and how certain you are that you NOW can predict the stock's motion. This whole thing is one of many reasons individuals are encouraged to work with index funds, and to buy-and-hold, rather than playing with individual stocks. It is essentially impossible to reliably "time the market", so all you can do is research a stock to death before making a bet on it. Much easier, and safer, to have your money riding on the market as a whole so the behavior of any one stock doesn't throw you into a panic. If you can't deal with the fact that stocks go down as well as up, you probably shouldn't be in the market.

The Delegates of the Press are led by the Secretary to the Delegates, who serves as OUP's chief executive and as its major representative on other university bodies. Oxford University Press has had a similar governance structure since the 17th century. The press is located on Walton Street, Oxford, opposite Somerville College, in the inner suburb of Jericho.
For the last 500 years, OUP has primarily focused on the publication of pedagogical texts and continues this tradition today by publishing academic journals, dictionaries, English language resources, bibliographies, books on indology, music, classics, literature, history, as well as bibles and atlases.

Rosenberg believes his team's approach has the potential to revolutionize the way we look at and manage insomnia. He notes that more than 90 million adults in the United States suffer from insomnia, and the condition is linked to increased risk of depression, hypertension, and heart disease, among other serious health concerns.

In the future, Rosenberg hopes Insomnia Ventures can help put an end to the stigma around sleep, and he envisions a world where sleep is just as important as other health concerns like nutrition and exercise.

"The key to making an impact is understanding the biology and physiology behind sleep," Rosenberg says. "We are doing things that have never been done before in this space and that gives us a huge opportunity to make a difference."

text:
Self-determination theory (SDT) is a macro theory of human motivation and personality that concerns people's innate growth tendencies and innate psychological needs. It pertains to the motivation behind people's choices in the absence of external influences and distractions. SDT focuses on the degree to which human behavior is self-motivated and self-determined.
In the 1970s, research on SDT evolved from studies comparing intrinsic and extrinsic motives, and from growing understanding of the dominant role that intrinsic motivation played in individual behavior. It was not until the mid-1980s Edward L. Deci and Richard Ryan wrote a book titled "Self-Determination and Intrinsic Motivation in Human Behavior" that SDT was formally introduced and accepted as a sound empirical theory. Since the 2000s, research into practical applications of SDT has increased significantly.
The key research that led to the emergence of SDT included research on intrinsic motivation. Intrinsic motivation refers to initiating an activity because it is interesting and satisfying in itself to do so, as opposed to doing an activity for the purpose of obtaining an external goal (extrinsic motivation). A taxonomy of motivations has been described based on the degree to which they are internalized. Internalization refers to the active attempt to transform an extrinsic motive into personally endorsed values and thus assimilate behavioral regulations that were originally external.
Edward Deci and Richard Ryan later expanded on the early work differentiating between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation and proposed three main intrinsic needs involved in self-determination.[10] According to Deci and Ryan, three basic psychological needs motivate self-initiated behavior and specify essential nutrients for individual psychological health and well-being. These needs are said to be the universal and innate need for autonomy, competence, and relatedness.
label: hc3human

text: Stem cells are special types of cells that have the ability to develop into many different types of cells in the body. Adult stem cells are found in various tissues in the body and can give rise to different types of cells within that particular tissue. For example, blood stem cells can turn into different types of blood cells, such as red blood cells and white blood cells. Embryonic stem cells are found in very early stage embryos and have the ability to develop into any type of cell in the body. Stem cells are being studied for many different medical applications. For example, they may be able to help treat conditions like diabetes, heart disease, and spinal cord injuries. However, stem cell research is a complex and rapidly evolving field, and there is still much that researchers do not know about these cells. There are many factors that can influence funding for stem cell research, including the cost of the research, the potential benefits of the research, and the risks associated with the research. text: No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing.Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is a measure of the expected return on an investment in real estate. It is calculated by dividing the net operating income (NOI) of a property by its current market value. The higher the cap rate, the higher the expected return on the investment. For example, if a property has a cap rate of 8% and it is worth $100,000, the expected return on the investment would be $8,000 per year.Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a measure of a company's profitability. It is calculated by dividing the company's net income by its net sales. Net income is the company's total revenue minus its expenses, while net sales is the company's total revenue minus its returns and allowances. The higher the net profit margin, the more profitable the company is. For example, if a company has a net profit margin of 10% and its net sales are $100,000, its net income would be $10,000.While both measures are used to assess the performance of an investment or a business, they are calculated differently and provide different types of information. Cap rate is specific to real estate investments, while net profit margin is used to measure the profitability of a business.

text:
For decades, readers have celebrated the classic whodunit — the suspenseful, puzzle-packed tale in which a smart detective pits his or her wits against a criminal genius, seeking to uncover the killer.

But two new novels suggest that this venerable formula is ripe for reinvention — to the delight of mystery fans. Dutch author Gerbrand Bakker's The Detour and British writer Wyl Menmuir's The Many are both set in isolated, rural places with an air of timelessness. And the stories in each are driven not by the desire to solve a crime but rather by the searching curiosity of their protagonists.

The Detour, which is set in the Welsh countryside, begins when a 70-year-old Dutch academic named Henk drives over the Severn Bridge, intent on investigating a peculiar rumor. It seems that his grandfather, Jos, left Holland 70 years earlier, and that he's never been heard from since.

In a tale that's part detective story, part meditation on the vagaries of memory and the way that time erodes the meaning of certain moments in our lives, Henk quietly uncovers bits and pieces of Jos' past. As the riddles add up, he finally learns where his grandfather has been all these years — and finds an answer to a mystery that he's been pondering for decades.

The Many is an even more ambitious story, drenched with the uncanny atmosphere of its Cornish seaside village setting. Through an unspeakable crime, an anonymous narrator has been reduced to a hollow man, unable to process his own pain.

His search for the truth leads him on a nightmarish journey through a series of strange encounters. One conversation leads to another, like a game of twisted pick-up sticks, until our narrator discovers the enigmatic connection linking everyone in the village — and how it is linked to him.

Bakker and Menmuir have crafted page-turners that carry the freshness of Gothic literature. Both novels unleash a fantastic atmosphere in which the secrets of the past finally catch up with the present — although nothing is resolved in a tidy package.

Rather, these two authors take the whodunit and re-imagine it as a canvas for their own novelistic vision. When their detective protagonists stumble on the truth of what happened, the narratives don't satisfy with a neat conclusion, but rather focus on the emotional fallout of the discovery.

This is where the real literary pleasures lie. Henk and the narrator of The Many are forced to confront the fact that, even when we know the answers, how to deal with them is a task that is uniquely our own.

Gold prices jumped to a six-month high on Tuesday, buoyed by optimism around the reopening of the Chinese economy, with the yellow metal settling at a near seven-year high.

Spot gold rose 0.8% to $1,947.58 per ounce by the close of trading in London, its highest since June. Prices in U.S. futures for December delivery added 0.7% to settle at $1,947.90 an ounce.

Analysts said that the reopening of the world's second-largest economy, which is gradually returning to normal following the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic, is supportive of gold prices.

China's recovery could help to drive a long-term uptrend in gold prices, which are seen as a hedge against inflation and currency devaluation, analysts said.

"The Chinese New Year is coming up at the end of January and that could mark the start of a new bullish chapter for gold," said Tai Wong, head of metals trading at BMO Capital Markets in New York.

The strength of gold prices is also likely to benefit from the extremely low interest rates in both the U.S. and other major economies.

The Federal Reserve and other central banks have kept interest rates at record lows since the start of the pandemic, and are unlikely to move them higher in the short-term. Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding gold and other non-yielding assets.

Gold prices have also been boosted by safe-haven demand, as investors seek out assets to protect them from the impact of the coronavirus.

The yellow metal has gained over 25% since the start of 2020, making it one of the best-performing assets this year.

The rally has prompted some investors to take profits at higher levels, but analysts said that there could be further gains ahead.

"There's still room to go higher as investors focus on the positives and look ahead to a post-COVID world and focus on the inflationary theme that is likely to play out over the next few years," said Margaret Yang, market analyst at CMC Markets in Singapore.

Yang added that gold could rise to $2,000 an ounce in 2021, as long as a COVID-19 vaccine is found and the global economy starts to recover.

Analysts also warned that a rise in US Treasury yields, if it were to occur, could weigh on gold prices, although they said that this is unlikely in the near-term.

Looking ahead, investors are awaiting the outcome of the two Georgia run-off elections, which will decide whether Democrats or Republicans will control the US Senate.

The US dollar has also been on a volatile path in recent days, after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said earlier this month that the U.S. economy still needs support from fiscal and monetary policies.

With no immediate catalysts, analysts said that gold prices will likely be driven by global risk sentiment, inflation expectations and monetary policy in the near-term.
